Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fruit

loans.name: Fuerza En Cristo Group

texts.es:
El grupo Fuerza en Cristo está integrada por tres personas trabajadoras y emprendedoras provenientes de la comarca valle de la laguna un pueblo pesquero de Masaya. El coordinador del grupo es el joven Juan José F. R. quien inicio vendiendo pan pero desde hace tres años junto con su esposa empezó a producir  y distribuirlo dicho producto ya que de esta manera generan mayores ganancias. 

Filiarte tiene la meta de expandir su negocio pero lo principal para lograrlo es tener su propio horno lo cual le permitiría elaborar mayor cantidad y variedad de productos, ya que  actualmente alquila un horno donde solamente producen dos arroaz diario.  Ellos invertirán el crédito en la producción con la compra de materia prima como harina, levadura, leche...etc. para cumplir con sus pedidos.

 Las otras integrantes son María Adelia  L.  R. quien en 1974 empieza trabajar con productos químicos de limpieza como el pinesol y la cliorina los cuales se consumen regularmente en los hogares y 
Mercedes del Carmen S. de 44 años tiene una pequeña venta. Además compra y vende cosechas como jocotes, mango, mamones, paya, groseas etc. Ellas invirtieran el crédito en sus negocios.

Por otra parte cabe señalar que ellos han sido parte de los servicios no financieros de Adim es decir del proceso de capacitación y formación sobre género y desarrollo empresarial lo cual según comentaron les ayudado mucho a administrar e invertir sabiamente, a economizar y mejorar su autoestima.
texts.en:
The group “Fuerza en Cristo” (Strength in Christ) consists of three hardworking and enterprising individuals from the fishing town of Masaya in the valley region of Laguna. The group coordinator is a young man named Juan José F. R.. Three years ago, he started selling bread that his wife produces. He distributes this product in order to generate more income.

F. has a goal of expanding his business, but his main objective is to have his own oven which would allow him to produce greater quantities and a wider variety of products. He currently rents an oven that that only produces two batches per day. F. will invest his loan in the purchase of raw materials such as flour, yeast, milk, and other items so that he can complete his orders.

Another member is María Adelia L. R., who in 1974 began selling chemical cleaning products such as Pine Sol and chlorine. Such products are used regularly by many households. Mercedes del Carmen S. is 44 years old and has a small shop. In addition, she buys and sells jocotes (a type of plum), mangos, mamoncillos (a fruit native to the Caribbean and Latin America), papaya, currants, and other fruits. They will invest their loans in their businesses.

Also worth noting is that they have participated in nonfinancial services offered by ADIM, such as training classes in product creation and business development. According to them, these services have helped them to manage and invest wisely, economize, and improve their self-esteem.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase raw materials such as flour, yeast, milk, and other items

loans.name: Azra Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Muniran wants a loan to buy material (beads, colored thread and cloth) for her decorative embroidering business. Naseem Un Nisa wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. 

Azra parveen is the wife of M. A. A. and lives in a city called Arifwala in Pakistan. She has given birth to three children and all of them are getting an education from a local school. 

Azra is a seamstress and sews clothes for her neighbors. She utilizes her income to pay the utilities. Her husband runs a grocery shop in the community. She is applying for a loan to buy groceries (lentils, cooking oil, and rice) to diversify her husband’s grocery shop into a store.

loans.use: To buy groceries for her grocery shop

loans.name: Mercedes Group

texts.es:
El grupo Mercedes está integrado por  tres féminas trabajadoras y emprendedoras una de ellas es Milagro de Jesús Bermúdez Sosa  una señora humilde que sueña con tener un terreno para construir ahí su casa. Esta desde hace quince años se dedica a la compra y venta de leña. Ella según comento inicio con poco pero conforme a los créditos su negocio ha mejorado ya que con los préstamos adquiere mayor cantidad de leña.

Otra de las integrantes es Mauda Patricia M. Bermúdez quien tiene una pequeña pulpería.  Mientras Lucero Gaviota L. Garay una joven risueña y decidida para poder costear sus estudios universitarios empezó a comercializar productos de la Zermat. Ella actualmente  está en el último año de la carrera de Trabajo Social.

Ellas invertirán el crédito para ampliar sus respectivos negocios con la compra de mayor cantidad de mercadería.
texts.en:
The Mercedes Group consists of three hardworking and enterprising women. One of them is Milagro de Jesús Bermúdez Sosa. She is a modest woman who dreams of having her own land for building a house. For the past fifteen years, she has been buying and selling firewood. According to her, she started with little and the loans have helped to shape and improve her business. She wants to acquire more firewood.

One of the other members is Mauda Patricia M. Bermúdez, who has a small grocery store. Meanwhile, Lucero Gaviota L. Garay is a cheerful young woman who decided to earn money to pay for her university studies. She started selling products made by Zermat (a cosmetics line) and is in her last year before earning her degree in social work.

They will invest their loan to expand their respective businesses by purchasing large quantities of merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase firewood

loans.name: Rosauro

texts.es:
El Sr. Rosauro nacio en Ayacucho Santa Cruz el 7 de octubre de 1956. concubino (que no es casado pero vive en pareja)con la sra. Maria, ellos tienen 2 hijos que se encuentran en edad escolar. Hace 20 años que el señor compro su parcela en la banda del rio, son 20 hectareas. El señor Rosauro actualmente esta sembrando arroz, yuca, maiz y tambien tiene 3 hectareas de pasto para su ganado todo sus productos que el cosecha lo vende en el mercado central de el torno, le va muy bien en la siembra y cosecha y posterior comercializacion de sus productos.
  
El Sr. Rosauro  esta agradecido con la institucion por el apoyo  brindado ademas que es su primer credito, con el dinero del credito el Sr. Rosauro comprara semillas para sembrar Papa ya que es epoca de siembra y asi incrementar su capital de trabajo.

El Sr. Rosauro es una persona responsable y trabajadora con muchas ganas de superacion desea brindar a su familia toda la comodidad que el no tubo cuando era pequeño cuenta que quedo huerfano de muy pequeño y tubo que trabajar duro para salir adelante.
texts.en:
Rosauro was born in Ayacucho Santa Cruz on the 7th of October in 1956. He lives with a partner, Maria Isabel, and they have 2 children who are school-aged. Twenty years ago he bought a parcel of 20 hectares of land on the bank of a river. He currently cultivates rice, cassava root, corn, and he also has 3 hectares of pasture land for his livestock. He sells all of the products that he harvests in the central market of El Torno. He does very well planting, harvesting and selling his products. Rosauro is grateful to the institution for the support provided. In addition, this is his first loan, and with this money Rosauro will buy seeds to plant in the planting season and thus increase his working capital. Rosauro is a responsible and hard-working person with a strong desire to get ahead; he wants to provide his family with all of the comforts he lacked as a child. He was orphaned at a young age, and had to work hard to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seed to plant potatoes

loans.name: Jose Reynaldo

texts.es:
El señor Reynaldo M. es Agricultor y ganadero con 18 años de experiencia en los créditos que ha tramitado con anterioridad los ha cancelado sin ninguna dificultad los cuales los ha utilizado para siembra, compra de un tractor agrícola, mejoramiento de la vivienda y la finca, compra de ganado.

Actualmente lo utilizara para alquilar 4 manzanas de tierra para la siembra de arroz y mantenimiento del tractor.  
El Sr. M. ha tenido 8 créditos con la Institución y a la vez dice estar muy agradecido con Ceprodel por todo el apoyo que le han brindado siempre.
texts.en:
Mr. Reynaldo M. is a farmer and rancher with 18 years of experience. He has paid off his previous loans without any difficulty, and invested them in sowing crops, buying a tractor, improving his home and farm, and purchasing livestock. He will use the present loan to rent several acres of land for growing rice, and to repair his tractor. Mr. M. has received eight loans from this institution and says he's very grateful to Ceprodel for the support they've always given him.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Rent a parcel of land and repair his tractor

loans.name: Ileana Benita

texts.es: Ileana Betina tiene 37 años, es madre de familia tiene dos hijos que van al colegio, su  negocio es venta de ropa de manera ambulante, su esposo trabaja como albañil por cuenta propia el ayuda a su esposa a sufragar los gastos del hogar, por lo que el también ayuda a cuidar a sus hijas. Está solicitando un crédito para invertirlo en su negocio por el motivo que se acerca la temporada de semana santa sus clientes le están solicitando una variedad de productos. Sueña con obtener otro medio de ingreso como es una pulpería así podrá estar en su casa y velar por sus hijas.
texts.en:
Ileana Betina is 37 years old and a mother of two children who are attending high school. She sells clothing as a traveling merchant. Her husband works as a mason and helps his wife with covering the household expenses, which contributes toward the care of their daughters.

Ileana is requesting a loan to invest in her business because the Holy Week season is approaching and her customers are seeking a variety of products. She dreams of obtaining another source of income, such as a grocery store, to establish in her home so that she can look after her daughters.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Banda Development Group 1, Mukono

texts.en:
K. Deborah is a 47-year-old approachable and married mother of five school-going children. She runs a stationery shop and a clothing boutique in Banda, Mukono district.

Deborah has been operating her businesses for the last six years. A problem of street hawkers (vendors) dissuading her prospective clients is one she has had to come to grips with in this course of time. As a result, she has experienced a significant drop in her finances over some period of time.

Deborah reckons she makes close to 400,000 shillings a month. What has made her last in her business has been the good rapport she has struck with her remaining loyal clients. Her dream is to expand her boutique. She says this loan will help her maintain her stationery shop with more stock.

loans.use: To buy more stationery and clothes for resale in her businesses

loans.name: Maria Maxima

texts.es: La Sra. María  se dedica a la elaboración D. masas como Pan  pasteles tortas y variedad D. masitas, actividad con la que sustenta su hogar que esta conformado por tres integrantes el esposo y su hija la misma que  es niña especial ya que nació con retraso mental,  cuenta que fue difícil  la situación D. su hijita para ella y para su esposo ya que tiene que brindarle mas paciencia y amor y apoyarle toda la vida, pero la Sra. María es buena y muy trabajadora siempre pensando en mejorar la calidad D. su vida y brindar mejores oportunidades a su hijita  por lo que se decidió otorgarle la tasa preferencial, Con el dinero del credito comprara insumos po mayor para la elaboracion D. sus riquisimos productos, ella es muy conocida en el lugar por elaborar productos D. buena calidad y riquisimos tiene muchos clientes que le hacen pedidos para fiestas D. cumpleaños, ella esta muy agradecida con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgación del crédito.
texts.en:
María makes baked goods like breads, cakes, and a variety of pastries. With her income from this activity she is able to maintain her household, which includes her husband and her daughter. Her daughter is a special little girl who was born with some mental retardation. María says this situation was hard for her and her husband, since they have to proviD. lots of patience and love and will have to take care of their daughter for the rest of their lives, but María is a good, hardworking person who's always looking to improve her quality of life and offer better opportunities to her little girl, which is why she was offered a preferential loan. She will use the money to buy supplies at wholesale for creating her delicious goods. She is well known locally for her delicious, high-quality baked goods and has a lot of clients who order from her for birthday parties. She is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence they're placing in her by offering her the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies

loans.name: Suraiya's Group

texts.en:
Anaran wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Seeman wants a loan to buy items (shaving blades, scissors) for her family's barber shop. Manzooran wants a loan to buy a donkey cart. 

Suraiya is the group leader of the above-mentioned ladies. They all live in a city called Arifwala in Pakistan. Suraiya owns & operates her sewing clothes business. She sews clothes of her neighborhood ladies and generates income. She does this work to share the financial burden with her husband. 

Suraiya’s husband's name is N. M. and he is a loader by profession. He loads different items such as (cement, bricks) on his donkey cart and delivers them to different places and earns income. Currently, his cart has become rough and broken in different places. Therefore Suraiya is requesting a loan to buy a new donkey cart so that he will be able to continue his work without any gap.

loans.use: To buy a new donkey cart

loans.name: Juan Jose

texts.es:
El Sr. Juan R. es transportista del municipio del viejo.
El va a utilizar el crédito en la compra de llantas para mantener activo su bus ya que es el que le lleva el alimento diario a su hogar.
El Sr. R. ha tenido 18 créditos en la  Institución los cuales todos los ha pagado bien, y espera seguir trabajando si Dios se lo permite.
Además el dice sentirse muy agradecido con Ceprodel por la ayuda que le ha brindado todos estos años y dice estar muy agradecido.
texts.en:
Mr. Juan R. drives a bus in the town of El Viejo. He's going to use his loan to buy tires to keep his vehicle in good repair, since it's what allows to him to put food on the table. Mr. R. has had 18 loans with the institution, all of which he's paid off without any problems, and he hopes to continue working, God willing. He also says he feels very grateful to Ceprodel for the support they've offered him all these years.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase bus tires

loans.name: Banda Development Group 2, Mukono

texts.en:
N. Alice is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is a 53-year-old seamstress in Banda, Mukono district, and is a widow with two school-going children and a grandchild and a niece in her care. 

Alice has been a tailor for twenty-three years and attributes her long term survival in her business to the good working relationship she has with many of her clients. Presently, she is making profits of 140,000 shillings a month and hopes her financial prospects will improve once she can access a loan.

With using loans, Alice carries a strong belief that she will be able to open her own tailoring school, but this time around she needs to stock more clothing materials in bulk for business improvement.

loans.use: To buy more cloth in bulk

loans.name: Blenda Johana

texts.es:
Blenda C. de 27 años, vive en una zona periurbana en el Fortín de Guayaquil, su casa es de cemento y solo cuenta con luz, esta casada y tiene 1 hijo de 4 años. 

Ella era empleada en una fábrica de muebles pero como no podía darle una buena vida a su familia decidió invertir sus pocos ahorros en esponjas, pinturas, telas  y empezar en conjunto con su esposo la actividad de ebanista. 

Ya tiene 2 años siendo ebanista con su esposo, trabajan hasta las 17h00 todos los días. Ella y su esposo arreglan muebles dañados y los dejan como nuevos para sus clientes. 
Con el préstamo quiere comprar materiales como esponjas, telas, pinturas y diluyente para arreglar mas muebles. 

En el futuro quiere que su taller se convierta en una de la más grande ebanistería de Guayaquil y así asegurar el futuro de su familia.
texts.en:
Blenda C. is 27 years old and lives in the periurban area of Fortín in Guayaquil. Her house is made of cement and receives electricity. She is married and has a four year old son.

Blenda was employed at a furniture factory, but this did not provide a good life for her family. She decided to invest some of her savings in sponges, paints, and cloths to start working with her husband in his cabinetmaking business.

Her husband has been a cabinetmaker for two years, working until 5pm every day. Blenda and her husband repair their customers’ damaged furniture and make them like new. With this loan, she will buy materials such as sponges, cloths, paints, and thinner for repairing furniture.

In the future, she wants to convert her workshop into a larger cabinetmaking business in Guayaquil so that she can secure her family’s future.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sponges, cloths, paints, and thinner

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia is a 39-year-old single mother of two from Paraíso de Cartago located in the central valley of Costa Rica. She has had to fight hard in order to improve living conditions for herself and her two children.

Patricia has worked over the past ten years selling podiatrist (foot treatment) services. She learned how to work in podiatry as an employee in a clinic many years ago. She opened her business with an initial investment of 20,000 colones. She specializes in providing podiatry services to clients living with diabetes as well as to seniors.

This will be Patricia’s second loan with Fundación Mujer; her first loan was paid back on time and in full. Her goal is to increase her client base in order to earn more revenues and continue to provide a quality standard of living for her children.

In a good month Patricia might earn 600,000 colones and in a bad month, only 200,000. She dedicates eight hours a day to her business, while her children are at school. Patricia hopes to use the revenues from her business to finance housing costs, invest in home improvements, re-invest in her business, make contributions to her savings, and to repay her loan.

The income generated from Patricia’s business represents 90% of family income and is used to finance the living expenses of Patricia and her two children. Her long term goals are to open her own clinic and to invest in higher quality education for her children. 

Recently, Patricia had a car accident. The use of her vehicle is central to the operation of her business as she uses it to visit clients and carry out her daily routine. She will use this loan to finance repairs to her car so that she can continue to work towards the expansion of her business. At the moment, she is using a car borrowed from a friend to conduct her business.

Patricia says her only obstacle is time. If she had somebody to help her perform some of her domestic tasks, she would be able to dedicate more time to her business.

loans.use: To repair her car which she uses in her business

loans.name: Kiwogo Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
B. Fausita appears at the top left in the small photo and also appears in the group photo. She is 40 years old and is a reserved married woman with four children, all going to school.

Fausita has been operating a beauty salon in Butebe zone, Mukono district, for the last seven years. Despite her good-humored nature, her biggest business challenge since she began has always been defaulting clients who have always taken her kindness for a weakness.

Fausita calculates that she makes close to 100,000 shillings per month. She plans on expanding her business stock and financial base once her business can get that much needed boost of a loan.

loans.use: To buy more hair chemicals, hair dyes, hairpieces, etc., for her salon expansion

loans.name: Esperanza Del Este Group

texts.es:
Este comenzó mediante algunas integrantes quienes se reunieron e invitaron a sus amigas y lograron conformar el comité que hasta ahora trabaja con mucho compromiso y empeño en salir adelante mejorando las condiciones de vida de sus familias con el trabajo solidario. 
Ellas se ayudan mutuamente y ademas reciben asesoramiento constante sobre el manejo de varios temas relacionados a la planificación familiar especialmente, y de como manejar el negocio para obtener mejores resultados con buenas ganancias.
Una despensa donde ofrece todo tipo de productos de uso domestico es la posee la señora Mirta A.. Su negocio es atendida por ella y en ocaciones por sus hijos o por el marido quien constantemente le apoyan en cada actividad que realiza.
El crédito solicitado fue para la compra de mercaderías faltantes en su negocio como lactes, panificados, pastas, embutidos y otros.
texts.en:
This group started when a few members got together, invited their friends, and were able to form a committee. They now work with great commitment and determination to succeed and improve their families’ living conditions through their mutual efforts. The members help one another and receive ongoing advice on various issues, particularly those related to family planning and managing their businesses to achieve good results and better earnings.

Sra. Mirta A. is a member who has a general store where she offers all types of household products. She manages her business, and occasionally has the help of her children or her husband, who have been a constant source of support for each of her activities. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy merchandise she is lacking such as dairy products, baked goods, pasta, cured meats, and other items.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase dairy products, baked goods, pasta, cured meats, and other items

loans.name: Dulce Maria

texts.es:
La Sra. Dulce María Hernández Álvarez tiene una pequeña ventecita en su casa de habitación que esta ubicada en el municipio de El viejo. 

Ella va a utilizar el crédito para surtir su  negocio  en la compra de arroz, frijoles, azúcar, aceite, etc.
Ella es madre de 3 hijos y vive con ellos y su esposo.
Y hoy en día dice estar agradecida con CEPRODEL, por darle la oportunidad de poder crecer en su negocio así como en su vida personal.
texts.en:
Dulce María Hernández Álvarez has a small store in her home, which is located in the municipality of El Viejo. She will use this loan to restock her business by purchasing rice, beans, sugar, cooking oil, etc. She is the mother of 3 children and she lives with them and with her husband. Today she says that she is grateful to CEPRODEL for giving her this opportunity to grow her business as well as her personal life.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy products to sell such as rice, beans, bread, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Danilse Esther

texts.es:
Danilse Esther V. D., vive  en la casa de su madre en el Barrio Las Dunas de Barranquilla, desde los 18 años trabajó en un salón de belleza y estética donde aprendió el oficio de hacer masajes corporales y desde ese momento no ha abandonado esa actividad, que combina con la venta de mercancía especialmente cosmética, mediante catálogos, actividades que combina  perfectamente, pues ofrece sus cosméticos a los mismos clientes que reciben su servicio; Danilse tiene 3 hijos de 9, 11 y 18 años y está muy feliz porque hace 2 años está pagando un lote en el Macroproyecto Vivienda Villas de San Pablo, apoyado por la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, y ya obtuvo el subsidio del estado Colombiano;  así que muy pronto estará en su casa propia con sus tres hijos y también tendrá en ese nuevo sitio un nuevo potencial de clientes, pues piensa realizar su negocio  de masajes  y venta de mercancías desde su nueva vivienda. Para Danilse es muy importante estar al frente de la tecnológica de la informática y  que sus hijos también progresen, con este novedoso avance,  por eso solicita un crédito por valor de $1.500.000 que le permita comprar un computador, donde aprenda con sus hijos a operarlos y a manejar su negocio, para que ellos le tomen amor al trabajo.
Cuando Ingresó a la Fundación Santo Domingo  hace mas de tres años, la llevó una amiga y desde ese momento ha recibido 4 créditos, los cuales le han servido para mejorar su negocio y ofrecer mejores servicios, utilizando cremas, ungüentos y cosméticos relajantes, que sus clientes también le compran; ella no deja de soñar con el momento en que se pase para su vivienda en Villas de San Pablo y quiere que sus hijos se eduquen y sean unas personas de bien. Y es su máxima desafío.
texts.en:
Danilse Esther V. D. lives at her mother’s house in the neighborhood of Las Dunas in Barranquilla. From the age of 18, she has worked at a beauty salon and aesthetics practice where she learned how to administer body massages. Since then, she has never abandoned this activity. Danilse also sells cosmetics through a catalog and is able to combine both of these activities perfectly. She offers her cosmetics to the same customers who receive massage services.

Danilse has three children (ages 9, 11, and 18). She is very happy because two years ago she bought a lot in the Macro-project Housing Village in San Pablo with the help of Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. She also obtained a state subsidy from the Colombian government, so she and her three children will be able to have their own home. As a result, Danilse will have another location for serving potential customers to her business because she plans to provide massage services and sell cosmetics from her new home. She knows it is very important to be at the forefront of information technology and allow her children to also progress with these new breakthroughs. Therefore, she is requesting a loan in the amount of 1,500,000 COP to purchase a computer that she will use to manage and operate her business. She will learn with her children how to operate it because they love working with computers.

When she started with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo three years ago, she came with a friend and from that moment has taken out four loans that have helped to improve her business. She now offers better service by utilizing crèmes, ointments, and relaxing cosmetics that her customers also buy. Danilse still dreams for the moment when she can spend time at her home at Villas de San Pablo. She also wants to see her children become educated and develop into good people. These are her main challenges.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a computer for her business

loans.name: Kely Yohanna

texts.es:
Kely A. vive en el barrio Los Ángeles en el occidente de Barranquilla, con sus dos hijos de 7 y 3 años de edad y su esposo que trabaja en la arquidiócesis de esta misma ciudad. Kely tiene 27 años y vende tanto prendas de plata y de oro golfi como útiles escolares a crédito. Se dedicó a la venta de mercancía desde muy joven; ella inició vendiendo productos, desde cuando era adolescente a sus compañeras del colegio. Hubo momentos en que la familia sólo vivía de vender prendas, sin embargo, con eso pudieron comprar el pequeño lote que ahora habitan y que han construido gradualmente;  En su negocio tienen una vitrina donde exhibe variedades y adornos, pero su mayor clientela son los empleados, compañeros de su esposo y asistentes en una clínica donde le practican  terapias de recuperación  a su niña menor. Este es su primer crédito con la Fundación, entidad a que fue recomendada por su hermano que también está vinculado a esta organización. Con el  crédito de $1.500.000 que actualmente solicita Kely va a  surtir su vitrina y comprar ropa de niños, bolsos, prendas de plata y oro golfi que tiene encargados, este es un  surtido   que tiene mucha salida en su mercado doméstico.
El barrio en que vive Kely se ha ido mejorando a lo largo de los años: inicialmente no tenía servicios pero gradualmente la comunidad se reunió para conseguirlos y ahora han rellenado las calles y han ido urbanizando los lotes para alcanzar el estado en que ahora se encuentra y lo hace más vivible. Su meta es invertir el dinero de sus utilidades en su casa para hacerle un buen mejoramiento.
texts.en:
Kely A. lives in the Los Angeles neighborhood of east Barranquilla with her two children, 7- and 3-years old, and her husband, who works for the city's archdiocese. Kely is 27-years old and makes a living selling costume jewelry. She has been an entrepreneur since she was a girl, selling first to her school friends when she was a teenager. At times, the family lived on her sales but she was ultimately able to buy the small lot where they now live and they have gradually developed it. She has a glass case for the business where she can display her products but her best customers are her husband's co-workers and the nurses and aides at a rehabilitation center where she takes her daughter for treatment. This is the first time that Kely has applied to the Fundacion for a loan. Her brother, who has links with the bank, recommended that she apply. She will use the $1,500,000 loan to stock her business. She will buy children's clothing, bags, costume jewelry, all products that her target customers are likely to buy. The neighborhood where Kely lives has improved over the years. It had few services before but the neighbors banded together to get them and now the streets are paved and the properties are being registered so that they can get services more easily in the future. Her ultimate goal is to invest her earnings in her house to make it more liveable.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products for resale.

loans.name: Lidia Azucena

texts.es: Lidia Azucena tiene 34 años, su actividad económica es la venta de mariscos. Hace más de 10 años que se dedica a este negocio, pues es el único medio de ingreso que tiene. Lidia tiene 4 hijos y todos dependen de ella, por lo que es una mujer muy trabajadora todos los días ella va comprar sus productos en el puerto donde los compra mucho más favorable, para ella ofrecerlos mucho más accesibles. El financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de camarones, pescado y punches que es lo que más demandan sus clientes. Su deseo es seguir trabajando y seguir proporcionando a sus hijos los estudios necesarios.
texts.en:
Lidia Azucena, 34, operates a seafood sales business. She has operated the business for more than 10 years and it is her only source of income. Lidia has 4 children who also depend on her income. It's for them that she works hard, going every day to the port where she can buy supplies of seafood for relatively little so that she, in turn, can offer the best prices to her customers. The loan that she is applying for will be used to buy shrimp, fish and other products that her customers want. Lidia's greatest hope is that she can keep on working and providing her children with a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Mariposas Blancas Group

texts.es: El grupo “Mariposas Blancas” esta representado por la señora Blanca y conformada por 10 miembros D. los cuales 4 son varones y el resto mujeres todos residentes D. la misma zona. La señora Blanca esta casada, su esposo se llama Rolando y tiene 3 hijos pequeños que todavía no van al colegio, Blanca se dedica a la venta D. sillpancho en su domicilio y atienD. todos los días,  vive en la casa D. sus suegros y su expectativa es crecer y adquirir un terreno para tener mas independencia. El resto del grupo tiene diferentes actividades la mayoría se dedica a la venta D. cosméticos pero otras venden verduras y comida, entre los varones se dedican al transporte D. pasajeros como chóferes, albañilería al servicio  en talleres mecánicos y chaparía.  El grupo en general tiene experiencia en los negocios que desempeñan y ponen todo su entusiasmo para salir adelante por lo que no le dan mucha importancia  a la competencia ya que cuentan con clientes leales a sus productos. El crédito será utilizado para incrementar su capital D. operación y para la compra D. insumos, mercadería y herramientas D. trabajo. El grupo es nuevo y su expectativa es seguir trabajando con la institución para crecer y otorgarle a su familia una mejor calidad D. vida.
texts.en:
The Mariposas Blancas (White Butterflies) Group, represented by Mrs. Blanca, is composed of 10 members -- 6 women and 4 men, all residing in the same zone. Blanca is married – her husband is Rolando -- and she has 3 little ones who don't yet go to school. Blanca sells sillpancho (a local dish) from her home and attends customers every day. She lives in her in-law's house and her goal is to grow economically and acquire land in order to have more independence. The remainder of the group is engaged in different activities. The majority sell cosmetics while others sell vegetables and meals. The men transport passengers as chauffeurs, or work as masons, or in shops as mechanics or making chaps. The group generally has experience in the businesses they have and employ all their enthusiasm to get ahead. They don't worry about the competition, since they can count on loyal customers to buy their products. The loan will be used to increase their operating capital, buying supplies, merchandise, and work tools. The group is new and their intentions are to continue working with our institution in order to grow and proviD. their families with a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING SUPPLIES, MERCHANDISE, AND WORK TOOLS

loans.name: Yelba Argentina

texts.es:
La señora Yelba Argentina L. Ampié, tiene la edad de 25 años, vive con su esposo, en el humilde Barrio San Ignacio, ellos son una familia de 4 miembros, y dentro de los principales sueños que tienen para la familia, está el mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda, ellos son agricultores desde hace 5 años.

Fue con el apoyo de su papa, que comenzaron a cosechar y uno de los principales problemas que han tenido, ha sido la afectación de las plagas y las enfermedades de las tierras, es por esta razón que el solicita un préstamo para la compra de fungicidas y abonos, para brindarle mantenimiento a su producción, esto les traerá un aumento en el volumen de sus ventas y de esta  forma mejores condiciones económicas para futuros proyectos que les favorezcan a su estabilidad económica.
texts.en:
Sra. Yelba Argentina Lopez Ampie, 25, lives with her husband in the humble neighborhood of San Ignacio. Her family of 4 has lots of dreams for the future but one of the most important is to improve their standard of living. They have operated a farming business for the last 5 years. They started their first crop with help from her father but the soil is exhausted and they have problems with pests so they need a loan in order to buy pesticides and fertilizers. By improving their output, they can increase their sales and, in turn, their economic condition and future financial stability.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and pesticides for farming business.

loans.name: Wokulira Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
N. Annet, shown at the top left as well as in the group photo, is a very hardworking lady with a restaurant business. She is a single mother of three children who are all in school and this is the best reason why she works so hard.

Annet prepares breakfast, lunch and supper for her customers in Nabuti. She is able to make 75,000/= as weekly income and she says that this would be more except that at times the food prices are hiked due to external factors.

Annet needs to expand her business further by being able to prepare a variety of foodstuffs as well as building a comfortable home. She needs a loan to be able to buy more foodstuffs for her restaurant.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for her restaurant

loans.name: Bawanguzi Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
N. Felista, shown in the small photo at the top left, also appears in the group photo. She is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is a 35-year-old friendly lady who is married with four children, all in school.

Felista owns a school in Nabuti that has been operational for four years and she is grateful that the loans have helped her in running it. She hopes to continue improving the academic standards of her school so that her pupils can be good and successful citizens.

Felista also hopes to expand her school further but needs a loan to help with buying more foodstuffs in bulk for the school.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs in bulk for her school

loans.name: Paraiso Group

texts.es: El banco comunal “Paraíso” representado por el señor Armando y conformado por 10 socios que entre ellos son bien unidos, alegres  y muy dinámicos. La señora Inés es la socia destacada del grupo ella se dedica  a la venta D. F. en la zona D. Chimore senda 3 y su esposo Felipe se dedica a la venta D. plátano (saca del chaco para vender) tienen 2 hijos que todavía son pequeños, Inés y su esposo aun viven en la casa D. los padres D. ella, por lo que su mayor deseo es poder comprarse un terreno donD. sembrar para progresar y poder darles a sus hijos un futuro mejor. El resto del grupo se dedica a diferentes actividades, la mayoría trabaja en lo que es la venta D. F., ropa, frutas y entre los varones se dedican a la mecánica, transporte, construcción y a la agricultura. El grupo en general tiene experiencia en los negocios que desempeñan y es por esta razón que son conocidos en toda la zona. La competencia en general es bastante amplia, el grupo cuenta con  clientes fijos que reconocen su trabajo y demandan sus productos y servicios. El presente crédito será utilizado como capital D. inversión para la compra D. F., compra D. materiales, insumos y herramientas D. trabajo que ayuden a generar un mejor ingreso para el sustento D. los hogares D. los socios. La expectativa que tiene el grupo es D. seguir trabajando y contando sobre todo con el apoyo económico D. la fundación que les ayuda a crecer para tener un hogar mas estable y mejor calidad D. vida.
texts.en:
The Paraíso (Paradise) Communal Bank is represented by Armando and comprised of ten members. They members are very united, happy, and very dynamic. Inés is the featured member of the group. She sells flowers in the Chimore Senda 3 area. Her husband, Felipe, sells bananas (he takes them from the farm to sell). They have two children who are still young. Inés and her husband still live in her parents’ house. Her biggest desire is to be able to buy a piece of land to plant. She wants to progress and be able to give her children a better future. The rest of the group works at different activities. Most of them work selling flowers, clothes, and fruits. The men work as mechanics, in transportation, in construction, and in farming. In general, the group has experience in the businesses they have. That is why they are well known in the entire area. In general, there is a lot of competition. The group has regular customers who recognize their work and demand their products and services. The current loan will be used as capital to invest in the purchase of flowers, materials, supplies, and work tools that will help to generate better income to support the members’ households. The group’s expectation is to keep working and counting, above all, on the economic support of the foundation to help them grow. They want this in order to have a more stable home and a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Sandra Vanessa

texts.es: Sandra Vanessa tiene mucho tiempo de trabajar con Fundación pues ha sido de gran ayuda. La actividad económica a la que se dedica es una pulpería, hace más de  12 años que se dedica a este negocio, desde un inicio a ella le ha gustado trabajar y ganarse su propio dinero, la mayoría de sus clientes son vecinos cercanos, Sandra es muy popular por ofrecer un gran atractivo que es ofrecer un espíritu alegre a sus clientes. El financiamiento que está solicitando es para la compra de golosinas, granos básicos, pan, productos de limpieza, pan, detergentes y galletas. Ella sueña con llegar a hacer madre ya que hasta el día de hoy no ha podido.
texts.en:
Sandra Vanessa has been a customer of Fundación Leon for a long time, as it has been of great help to her. She owns a small grocery store and has run this business for more than 12 years. From the beginning, she has enjoyed working and earning her own money. Most of her customers are nearby neighbors. Sandra is very popular with her customers because of her cheerful attitude. The requested loan is for the purchase of candies, basic grains, bread, cleaning products, detergents, and cookies. She has not been able to have children, but her dream is to become a mother.

Translated from Spanish by Jeff Schell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise for sale in her grocery store

loans.name: Omaira Judith

texts.es:
Omaira B. es una mujer emprendedora y trabajadora de 52 años de edad que vive en el barrio Las Nieves en el sur de Barranquilla, cerca de la vía principal donde hay muchos centros comerciales. Trabaja de una manera independiente principalmente a través de guías especializadas de productos, como ropa y cosméticos, pero también sabe manejar el mercado de calzados y aprovechar ofertas, descuentos o remates; con este fin, está pendiente de que hija que trabaja en un almacén de calzado le indique cuando hay tales oportunidades, pero para comprar así de contado se necesita capital y por eso ingresó a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo por recomendación  de una amiga. Ahora solicita un crédito de $2.000.000 que quiere invertir en la compra de calzado a un cuñado que tiene una comercializadora de calzado en Cartagena y se los vende a  los precios que a  él le salen al por mayor, así  incrementará sus ingresos.
Omaira inició su negocio cuando a su esposo lo trasladaron a La Guajira, otro departamento de Colombia en la parte más oriental de la costa caribeña y en ese momento, empezó a comercializar productos porque conocía los grandes almacenes de Barranquilla, debido a trabajos anteriores que  había realizado con estos y que aun en la actualidad  le ofrecen excelentes precios: sus clientes le encargan jeans y ella puede tener mucha utilidad con tales compras, así mismo una amiga que también vende mediante catálogo le da el  25% de utilidad a ella y ahora las dos tienen la meta de asociarse en un local para vender los productos que cada una comercializa; Omaira espera que encuentren un local en una esquina que servirá para incrementar los ingresos de ambas,  porque quiere ubicarse en un lugar más visible comercialmente
texts.en:
Omaira B. is 52 years old and an enterprising hardworking woman who lives in the neighborhood of Las Nieves in southern Barraquilla, which is near the main road where many shopping centers are located. She works independently selling through specialized guides that offer products such as clothing and cosmetics, but she also drives to the shoe store to take advantage of bargains, discounts, or discontinued models. Omaira is well-connected since her daughter works at a shoe warehouse and lets her know when such opportunities exist. However, she needs the capital to be able to buy these items, so she decided to join Fundación Mario Santo Domingo based on a friend’s recommendation. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of 2,000,000 COP so that she can purchase merchandise from a brother-in-law who has a shoe business in Cartegena and sells at wholesale prices, so she will be able to increase her profit margin.

Omaira began her business when her husband was transferred to La Guajira, another Colombian department in the eastern part of the country along the Caribbean coast. At that time, she sold her products because she was familiar with the large warehouses in Barraquilla. She had worked with them previously, and they still continue to offer excellent prices. Her customers are also requesting jeans, so she is finding that such purchases are very profitable. Omaira has a friend who also sells through a catalog and gives her a 25% cut of the profit. Their goal is to find a location where they both can sell their products. Omaira hopes to find a space on a street corner where they can increase their income because they both want to settle in a place that is more commercially visible.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase shoes

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es:
La señora Antonia es madre soltera, que emigró de Villarrica a Cuidad del Este para dar una mejor vida  sus hijas. 
La señora Antonia fue capaz de montar un pequeño local Comercial, donde ella vende  artículos de primera necesidad y otros artículos varios. 
Ella se inicio con un pequeño capital que su padre le había regalado y así fue creciendo poco a poco su negocio, hoy día ella ya cuanta con local propio y un buen ingreso para poder educar a sus hijas que están cursando el nivel medio.
Sin embargo, ella necesita este préstamo para  aumentar su inventario de mercaderías, ya que se encuentra en un lugar muy concurrido por la gente. 
A demostrado ser una persona muy responsable con sus compromisos y trabajadora.
texts.en:
La señora Antonia is a single mother who emigrated from Villarrica to Ciudad del Este to give a better life to her daughters. La señora Antonia was able to obtain a small site, where she sells necessities and other items. She began with a small amount of capital given to her by her father, and her business has been growing little by little. Today she has her own site and a good income. She is able to educate her daughters, who are in middle school. Nevertheless, she needs this loan to increase her inventory of merchandise, for her store is very busy. She has demonstrated that she is very responsible regarding her obligations and her work.

Translated from Spanish by Jeff Schell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various merchandise:  sugar, rice, noodles, assorted soaps, and other items

loans.name: Saddy Adolfo

texts.es:
El señor Saddy Adolfo M. P., tiene la edad de 24 años es casado  y vive en el Reparto Juan Ramón Padilla, el es agricultor y desde hace 5 años se dedica a este tipo de actividad y fue gracias al apoyo físico y económico que logro evolucionar en este rubro.

Uno de los principales problemas a los cuales se ha enfrentado esta la falta de agua potable que afecta a todo el reparto, ya que él habita en un humilde lugar que sufre de la escases del vital liquido, y que por esta razón sus tierras se encuentran enfermas, él solicita de un préstamo para la compra de materiales agrícolas que permitan mejores condiciones a las tierras y garantice una cosecha de calidad, esto le permitirá el capital necesario para la compra de un tanque almacén de agua potable o la instalación de un sistema de riego que resguarde las cosechas.
texts.en:
24-year old Señor Saddy Adolfo M. P. is married and lives in Reparto Juan Ramón Padilla. He’s worked in agriculture for five years, and thanks to physical and financial support he’s managed to do well in this line of work. One of the main problems that he faces is the lack of potable water in the area. He lives in a simple place which suffers from a scarcity of this vital liquid. For this reason his land is poor. Saddy is asking for a loan to buy agricultural products to improve the soil so that he is guaranteed a good harvest. A loan would provide him with the necessary capital to buy a water storage tank or an irrigation system that will safeguard his crops.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy fungicides and other agricultural products

loans.name: Cristo Rey Group

texts.es: El grupo “Cristo Rey” esta representado por Liliana Martha e integrado por diez socios donde 9 son mujeres y 1 hombre, con actividad económica similar venta de productos por catalogo. La señora Guilfa es integrante del grupo madre soltera muy trabajadora tiene 4 hijos, uno ya es profesional, los otros están estudiando, ella es modista, confecciona ropa para damas de muy buena calidad con buena clientela, además también se dedica a la venta de cosméticos por catalogo, ella recibe la colaboración del padre de sus hijos con pensiones mensuales que sirve para su educación, a futuro ella espera poder producir en mayor cantidad las prendas de vestir para vender al por mayor y poder llevar a provincias abarcando mas para generar mejores ingresos para el sustento de sus hijos. El resto del grupo se dedica a la venta de material escolar, abarrotes, productos Argentinos, cosméticos, servicio de enfermería y al transporte de pasajeros. La expectativa que tiene el grupo es de seguir trabajando y contar sobre todo con financiamiento para poder alcanzar sus metas. La mayoría tiene experiencia en el rubro por lo que no temen a la competencia ya que tienen clientes que demanda su producto y requieren de sus servicios ya que son socias muy dinámicas y bien sociables. El crédito será destinado a capital de operaciones debido a que la demanda creció y ellas requieren de un capital para la compra de insumos, y mercadería. La mayoría tiene experiencia en créditos solidarios por lo que saben como manjar y administrar los fondos otorgados para su beneficio y el crecimiento de sus negocios ya que de ello depende el sustento de sus familias.
texts.en:
The group “Cristo Rey” (Christ the King) is led by Liliana Martha and consists of ten members, nine women and one man. They have similar business activities selling products by catalog. Sra. Guilfa is a member of the group who is a hardworking single mother with four children, one of whom is already a professional while the rest are in school. Guilfa is a dressmaker. She makes high-quality clothing for women and has a good clientele. In addition, she sells cosmetics through a catalog. Guilfa receives assistance from the father of her children with a monthly pension to help pay for their education. In the future, she hopes to produce garments in large quantities so that she can sell them in bulk and ship them to other provinces. This will generate more income for her to support her children.

The rest of the group is involved in selling school materials, groceries, products from Argentina, cosmetics, or providing services such as health care and transportation. They expect to continue working and rely on financing in order to achieve their goals. Most have experience in their respective fields, so they are not afraid of competition because they have customers who demand their products and services. The members are also very dynamic and quite sociable.

This loan will be used as operating capital because demand has increased and they need funding to purchase supplies and merchandise. Most of the members have previous experience working with solidarity loans, so they know how to handle and manage the funds to their benefit in order to grow their businesses and support their families.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Maria Darlin

texts.es:
María P. de 46 años, vive en una zona periurbana en la Perimetral de Guayaquil, su casa es de cemento y solo cuenta con luz, su esposo es vendedor de cocos con el tiene 5 hijos de 19, 17, 15, 13 y 3 años.  

Hace muchos años atrás inicio como vendedora de jugos de cocos en la calles de Guayaquil, caminando y vendiendo jugos es como conoció a su esposo poco a poco  formaron una familia y decidieron comprar un triciclo para tener mas ventas. 

En la actualidad vende cocos y jugos con la ayuda de su esposo. Trabajan desde las 09:00 am hasta las 18:00 pm todos los días, las mayores ventas que tienen es en el centro de Guayaquil.

El préstamo lo va a invertir en cocos y en otro triciclo para tener mayores ingresos. La meta de María es progresar en su negocio y que sus hijos tengan un buen futuro.
texts.en:
46-year old María P. lives in a suburban area of Guayaquil. Her house is made of cement, and she only has electricity. Her husband sells coconuts. They have five children aged 19, 17, 15, 13, and 3. Many years ago María started selling coconut milk in the streets of Guayaquil. It was while she was walking around and selling the milk that she met her husband. They got married and decided to buy a tricycle cart to get more business. Currently María sells coconuts and milk with help from her husband. They work from 9am to 6pm every day. Sales are best in the centre of Guayaquil. The loan will be used to buy coconuts and another tricycle cart so they can earn more money. María’s goals are to expand her business and provide a good future for her children

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy coconuts

loans.name: Bonanza (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Bonanza está ubicado en la  comunidad El  Carmen de Guzho en la ciudad de Cuenca, tierra privilegiada para el cultivo de maíz, donde su gente adulta mayor se dedica a la agricultura y los más jóvenes han migrado a las ciudades grandes del país o al extranjero. 

La señora Martha tiene 42 años de edad, se encuentra casada y ha procreado 4 hijos que se encuentran de 20, 17, 11, 8, su hija mayor  le ayuda en la venta de sus productos en el mercado, el de 17 trabaja como oficial de albañil y sus dos últimos  hijos estudian en la escuela Agustín C. Vintimilla de la comunidad,   su esposo trabaja como albañil y por ahora se encuentran construyendo su casa propia.

Nuestra socia  tiene un puesto en el mercado donde ofrece variedad de  granos tiernos y hortalizas, esta actividad  realiza desde sus siete  años ya que  ayudaba a su mamá y a los veinte y un años  empezó a  trabajar en su propio puesto donde labora desde las 4 a.m. para comprar los productos y se queda hasta las 6 p.m. los días lunes, miércoles, sábado y domingo, mientras que los días jueves y viernes trabaja en un salón de comidas en el que lleva cuatro años con un horario de  8 a.m. a  6 p.m.  a más de estos trabajos se da tiempo para la cría de pollos los cuales les vende en el mercado de Cuenca.

Este es su primer crédito con la fundación y se animó a formar parte del banco  comunal gracias a una compañera del mercado, con el dinero que reciba  va a comprar  zanahoria, tomate, cebolloa, acelga, col, lechuga  y crias de pollos, vitaminas y alimento para criarlos y también  techo ardex  para su casa.

Tiene como  meta  terminar de construir  su casa.


La señora  María Cruz Q. vive en la urbe de la ciudad de Cuenca con tres de los cinco hijos que concibió, los dos primeros son casados y viven independientes, su hijo de 23 años  trabaja como albañil y  le ayuda un poco económicamente con los gastos del hogar, su hija le ayuda en su puesto de  mercado y su último hijo estudia en el colegio técnico Turi, el casa en la que habitan es de su propiedad que la construyo sola con su esfuerzo,  su esposo viajo al exterior hace diez años en busca del sueño americano y estabilidad económica para toda su familia pero al llegar allá se olvidó de los suyos, nos comenta que cuenta con un nuevo compromiso con quien se encuentra rehaciendo su vida.

María Cruz se dedica a la venta de quesillo, queso y todo tipo de granos en el mercado, esta actividad la realiza hace 35 años, empezó en el mercado 12 de abril y ahora labora en el mercado de la  feria libre y ya son 21 años en este lugar, trabaja todos los días de la semana sin descansar uno solo, su horario es de 6 a.m. a  6 p.m. no tiene puesto propio por lo que trabaja recorriendo todo el mercado.

Este  es su primer crédito en la fundación y con ese dinero va a  comprar quesillo,  tomate, paiteña, zanahoria, acelga, col y otras legumbres para surtir su puesto en el cual invierte mucho dinero cada semana. Su mayor sueño es que su hijo estudie y llegue a ser un excelente profesional y cuente con un buen trabajo.
texts.en:
The Bonanza Community Bank is located in the community of El Carmen de Guzho in the city of Cuenca. Maize grows really well there, and the local adults work in farming. The younger people have moved to the big cities or overseas. 42-year old Sra. Martha is married and has four children aged 20, 17, 11, and 8. Her eldest daughter helps her with the sales of the produce in the market. Her 17-year old son works as a bricklayer, and the younger two are students at the local school called Agustín C. Vintimilla. Her husband is a bricklayer, and they are in the process of building their own home. Martha has a stall in the market where she sells different sorts of fresh grains and vegetables. She’s been doing this job since she was seven years old helping her mother. At the age of twenty one, she started her own stall where she works from 4 am buying produce and stays until 6pm on Mondays, Wednesdays, Saturdays and Sundays. On Thursday and Fridays she works in a cafe--she’s been doing this for four years--from 8am to 6pm. She also raises chickens to sell in Cuenca market. This is her first loan with the foundation. She was encouraged to join the community bank by one of her friends in the market. With the money she is going to buy carrots, tomatoes, onions, chard, cabbage, lettuce, and baby chicks. She will also buy vitamins and food for the chicks. In addition, Martha will buy Ardex roofing for her house. Her goal is to complete the construction of the house. Señora María Cruz Q. lives in the big city of Cuenca with three of her five children. The oldest two are married and live independently. Her 23-year old son is a bricklayer and gives her some money towards the household expenses. Her daughter helps her with the market stall, and her youngest son is a student at the Turi technical college. The house she lives in is her own, and she put in a lot of effort to build it. Her husband travelled overseas twelve years ago in search of the American dream and economic stability for the whole family, but when he got there he forgot about his family. María says she has a new partner with whom she is rebuilding her life. María sells quesillo (soft cheese), cheese, and all kinds of grains in the market. She’s been doing this job for 35 years. She began in the 12 de Abril market and now works in the Feria Libre market where she’s been for 21 years. She works there every day without a day off from 6am to 6pm. She doesn’t have her own market stall but walks around the market. This is her first loan with the foundation, and with the money she plans to buy cheese, tomatoes, onions, carrots, chard, cabbage and other vegetables to increase her stock. She spends a lot of money buying the produce each week. María’s dream is for her son to study hard, become a professional, and get a good job.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy vegetables, chicks, and roofing

loans.name: Cesar Gustavo

texts.es:
El Sr. Cesar es Carpintero  hace varios años, es casado con la Sra. Mirta tienen 2 hijos menores que aún van a la escuela primaria.
El tiene su propia carpintería donde fabrica los muebles, el vende a personas que se dedican a vender muebles a cuota.
El se Inicio en este negocio trabajando como ayudante de un tío que realizaba la misma actividad. 
Hoy día el es dueño de su propia carpintería. El Sr. Cesar solo genera los ingresos para llevar adelante los gastos de la casa y los estudios de sus hijos para darles una mejor vida.
, El motivo del préstamo es para la compra de una camioneta para poder trasladar mejor sus mercaderías y así poder así brindarle mejor servicio a sus clientes.
Hemos confiado en  el por ser una persona muy trabajadora y responsable a sus compromisos.
texts.en:
Cesar has been a carpenter for several years. He is married to Mirta and they have two minor children who are still in primary school. He has his own workshop where he makes furniture. He sells to people who sell furniture with financing. He started in this business as an assistant to an uncle who did this activity. Today he is the owner of his own workshop. Cesar only makes enough income to cover the household expenses and his children's education to give them a better life. The reason for the loan is to buy a pick up truck to be able to transport his merchandise in a better way and thus offer a better service to his customers. We have trusted him because he is a hardworking person and responsible with his commitments.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase wood

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Leopoldino

texts.es:
El Sr. Leopoldino es casado hace varios años tienen 4 hijos mayores todos ya están casado e independientes de ellos.
Juntos con su Sra. montaron un copetín en su casa que esta ubicado  en un barrio muy poblado de la zona, se iniciaron con un pequeño capital que consiguieron con otros trabajos que han realizaron anteriormente como asalariados (Guardia de Seguridad).
Gracias al trabajo que están realizando han  educando a sus hijos y comprando todas las necesidades de su hogar.
El Sr. Leopoldino además del copetín trabaja como Guardia de seguridad.
El ha demostrado ser una persona muy responsable y honesta en sus compromisos.
El ya tuvo otros créditos con nosotros y cumplió en forma excelente con sus obligaciones en esta ocacion solicitó para la compra de mercaderías para la venta en su negocio.
texts.en:
Mr. Leopoldino has been married for several years, they have 4 grown up children who are married and are independent.

Along with his wife they set up a snack bar in their home that is located in a very populated neighborhood in the area. They began their business with a small investment that they got from other jobs that they had done before as wage workers (security guard).

Thanks to the work they are doing, they have been able to educate their children and to buy all the household essentials.

Mr. Leopoldino besides working in the snack bar works as a security guard.

He has shown to be a very responsible and honest person in his obligations.

He has already had other loans with us and has met his obligations excellently, this time he needs the loan to buy merchandize to sell in his business.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various merchandize like sugar, rice, spaghetti, meats and others.

loans.name: Georgina Guadalupe

texts.es: Georgina tiene 51 años, ella se dedica a ofrecer el servicio de tricitaxi, por lo que tiene más de 9 años que tiene este negocio, por lo que junto a su esposo han pasado circunstancias muy difíciles, además de este negocio tiene su pequeña pulpería, los triciclos son su mayor fuente de ingresos, pues la mayoría de sus ingresos provienen de este medio de vida, por lo que junto a su esposo luchan cada día para obtener más ganancias. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo y comprar  ciertos repuestos para sus triciclos y un termo para las gaseosas y el hielo. Ella sueña seguir adelante con su negocio pues mantenerlo activo ha sido un gran reto.
texts.en:
Georgina is 51 years old. She has had a tricitaxi (a pedal powered three-wheeled taxi) for more than 9 years and along with her husband they have gone through some very difficult circumstances. Besides having the tricitaxi, she has her own convenience store. The tricycles are her biggest source of income and with her husband they struggle each day have more earnings. The loan is for work capital and to buy some spare parts for the tricycles and a thermos for the soft drinks and ice. Georgina dreams of continuing with her business since keeping it open has been a great challenge.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Work capital.

loans.name: Justina

texts.es: Doña Justina Gutiérrez M., reside en la ciudad de Somoto, y se dedica a dar clases como profesora de nivel de educación primaria, ella utilizara este préstamo para comprar materiales de construcción y pago de mano de obra, con este crédito quiere construir un muro o pared para tener una mayor seguridad en el patio de sus casa. Doña Justina comenzó a trabajar como profesora de educación primaria desde hace 12 años, el lugar donde ella trabaja como profesora es en una comunidad  rural a unos 8 km de Somoto, viaja todos los días por la mañana a impartir sus clases a los niños que viven en esa localidad y que no pueden viajar hacia Somoto para estudiar. Doña Justina con este crédito espera mejorar las condiciones de sus vivienda y de esta forma darles a sus hijos un lugar más digno y seguro  donde ellos  puedan vivir. Ya que ella es madre soltera de dos Hijos los que estudian por la mañana, la razón por la cual es madre soltera fue porque su ex esposo la abandono de forma irresponsable a ella y sus hijos sin darle ningún tipo de ayuda.   Doña Justina tiene 4 años de trabajar con Ceprodel se le han otorgado 6 créditos los cuales ha utilizado para ir poco a poco mejorando sus casa de habitación.  El beneficio que ella ha tenido es bastante importante, ya que ella tiene como ingreso único su salario como madre soltera y de este tiene que cubrir los gastos del hogar y estudios de sus hijos, con el crédito ella ha podido lograr ir poco apoco mejorando su casa y darles a sus hijos un mejor nivel de vida más digno.
texts.en:
Doña Justina Gutiérrez M. lives in the city of Somoto and works as a primary school teacher. With this loan she wants to build a wall around the patio of her house, for better security. She will use the money to pay for materials and labor. Doña Justina has been working as a teacher for 12 years. She works in a rural community 8 km from Somoto and travels everyday to teach to the children in this town, who can't get to Somoto to attend school. With this loan, Doña Justina hopes to improve her living conditions and give her children a decent, safe place to live. She is a single mother and her children go to school in the mornings. Doña Justina's ex-husband abandoned her and their children without giving them any kind of support. Doña Justina has been working with Ceprodel for 4 years. She has received 6 loans, which have been used to improve her home bit by bit. She has benefited greatly from this, as her only income is her salary, which must be used for household expenses and her children's studies. These loans have allowed her to slowly improve her home and provide her children with a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials: 16 bags of cement, 3 bags of sand, 300kg of iron rods.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Felix Antonio

texts.es: Félix Antonio tiene 56 años, tiene más de 20 años de trabajar con Fundación por lo que ha demostrado ser un excelente cliente. Tiene 5 hijos pero todos ellos viven de manera independiente, su actividad es brindar el servicio de reparación de aparatos electrodomésticos. El tiene muchos clientes que recurren a su vivienda para que el repare sus productos, la situación más difícil que ha enfrentado hasta los momentos es la poca afluencia de clientes. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo que será destinado para la compra de herramientas, piezas de abanicos, licuadoras entre otros productos. Su deseo es mejorar cada día su servicio.
texts.en:
Félix Antonio is 56 years old and for over 20 years has worked with the foundation (Kiva’s field partner) and has shown to be an excellent client. He has 5 children but they all live independently. Mr. Félix works repairing domestic appliances. He has a lot of customers that go to his home so that he can repair their products. The most difficult situation he has faced is the low influx of customers. The loan that he seeks is for work capital that will be used to buy tools, parts for fans, blenders among other products. His wish is to improve each day his work.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Work capital.

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
Doña Carmen Gutiérrez López, vive en la ciudad de Somoto a 35 km de Condega ella trabaja como profesora para el Ministerio de Educación y da clases de nivel primaria, en una comunidad de esa ciudad.
El crédito lo utilizara para comprar 12 láminas de zinc y 8 perlines metálicos, esto para construir el techo de la cocina de su casa de habitación. Con esto ella quiere mejorar la cocina que en la actualidad es de madera y ya está deteriorada y en épocas de invierno hay filtraciones de agua por esa razón ella pretende realizar en este momento esta reparaciones. Doña Carmen comenzó a trabajar como profesora desde hace 14 años e inicio dando clases de preescolar, continuo con sus estudios de magisterio  y cuatro años después comenzó a dar clases de primaria y lleva ya 10 años dando clases en este nivel.  Doña Carmen es profesora y da clases de primaria en una escuelita rural, ella viaja todos los días hasta la comunidad donde da clases a niños de esa zona rural que se llama santa Isabel. Doña Carmen antes de dedicarse a esta actividad de trabajo ella estudiaba magisterio por la mañana y por las tardes ella vendía fritanga, Enchiladas en su casa, con eso ella se ayudaba para costear sus estudios y la mantención de sus hijos también tenía el apoyo de su esposo quien hacia trabajos de carpintería.  Con este crédito doña Carmen espera resolver el problema que tiene en el techo de su casa y de esta forma brindarle mayor seguridad y  satisfacción a sus hijas quienes también se veían afectado por este problema, Doña Carmen es casada y madre de dos hijas  una de 17 años de edad que estudia su quinto año de bachillerato, y una  niña de 8 años que estudia tercer grado de primaria. El marido de doña Carmen actualmente está sin trabajo y por el momento esta ayudándole a los trabajos del hogar y continúa buscando trabajo pero se le ha hecho difícil ya que en nuestro país el nivel de desempleo es bastante grande. Doña Carmen lleva 4 años de trabajar con financiamientos con Ceprodel y ha recibido 6 créditos en todo este tiempo. Doña Carmen es una señora trabajadora y que trabaja como maestra pero el sueldo que ella gana es bajo debido a que en nuestro país este sector no es bien remunerado por problemas  presupuestarios y económicos, entonces ella con los créditos ha venido mejorando poco a poco su casa y con su ingreso como profesora cubre estos gasto y los del hogar, de esta forma se le está brindando una alternativa para que ella pueda resolver sus necesidades   y se puede decir que ha mejorado su nivel de vida.
texts.en:
Doña Carmen Gutiérrez López lives in the city of Somoto, 35km from Condega. She works in this city as a primary school teacher for the Ministry of Education. The loan will be used to buy 12 sheets of corrugated iron roofing and 8 metal beams to construct the roof of her kitchen. Her kitchen is made of wood and is in bad shape. In the winter it leaks, which is why she needs to make the repairs right now. Doña Carmen has been a teacher for 14 years. She started as a pre-school teacher, continued attending teacher college and 4 years later began to teach primary school. She now teaches at a small rural school, traveling everyday to the community of Santa Isabel. Before becoming a teacher, Doña Carmen would go to classes in the mornings, then sell fried snacks like enchiladas from her house in the afternoon. This helped her pay for her schooling and provide for her children. She also had help from her husband, who worked as a carpenter. With this loan, Doña Carmen hopes to fix her roof and provide better safety and satisfaction to her daughters, who are also impacted by this problem. Doña Carmen is a married mother of 2 daughters: one is 17 years old and in her 5th year of secondary school, the other is 8 years old and in the 3rd grade. Her husband is unemployed; he is currently helping out with housework while looking for work, but it is difficult because unemployment rates are high in the country right now. Doña Carmen is a hardworking woman but her income is low because teachers are not well paid, due to budgetary and economic problems in the country. With these loans, she has been able to slowly improve her house while using her teacher's salary to cover household expenses. Thus, she is able to pay for her necessities and can say that she has improved her quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 12 sheets of corrugated iron roofing and 8 metal beams.

loans.name: Alicia Del Socorro

texts.es:
La señora Alicia del Socorro R. H., tiene 62 años es madre soltera de dos hijos mayores de edades, que habitan con ella y le apoyan económicamente a la economía del hogar, ellos viven en el Barrio Camilo Chamorro, este es un conocido Barrio de Managua el cual reporta altos índices de delincuencia.

Ella tiene una pequeña pulpería la cual es su fuente de ingresos, ella habita en una casita que tiene más de 30 años de vejez, es por esta razón que solicita de un préstamo para la compra de materiales de construcción, y poder reconstruir la infraestructura de su hogar, ella es una mujer de edad que desea realizar esta inversión para dejarles su vivienda, a futuro como herencia a sus hijos. Esto le traería la tranquilidad, de que ellos habiten en un lugar cómodo y seguro para sus familias.
texts.en:
Mrs. Alicia del Socorro R. H. is 62 years old; she is a single mother of 2 grown up children. They live with her and support her economically for the household; they live in the Barrio Camilo Chamorro, a well-known neighborhood of Managua which is known for its high delinquency rate.

She has a small convenience store which is her source of income. She lives in a house that is more than 30 years old, and it is for this reason that she needs the loan, to buy construction materials that will be used to reconstruct the infrastructure of her home. She is an elderly woman who wishes to do this investment so that she can leave her home as an inheritance for her children. This will set her mind at ease, and they will be able to live in a comfortable and safe home for their families.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy materials for construction.

loans.name: Maria Cristina

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal María Monserrate pertenece a la ciudad de Montecristi en la provincia costera Manabí. 
La señora Cristina es casada y tiene cuatro hijos, ella se dedica al comercio ambulante desde hace 24 años, vende escapularios, llaveros, reliquias, velas todo lo que va relacionado con las imágenes católicas, tiene un pequeño negocio en su casa también los días domingos sale a vender en las afuera de la iglesia de Montecristi, además en las fiestas parroquiales de otros cantones ella viaja y época de navidad vende juguetes, fantasías (accesorios de mujeres) entre otros productos.

 La señora Cristina el dinero que esta solicitando es para incrementar mas su negocio ella viaja a la ciudad de Guayaquil para realizar sus compras como, lasos, zapatillas, estampas para arreglar los cuartos, de todo un poco, en cada compra que realiza invierte desde 800 a 1500 dólares, su esposo y su hijo le ayudan con el negocio , ella ha sido socia desde hace 24 años  ella ingreso al bankito por midió de unos extranjeros que llegaron a motivar a las personas de bajos recursos económicos dándoles a conocer que podían hacer prestamos a la Fundación Espoir para así poder iniciar sus negocios  cuenta que estos señores les daban las charlas de motivación y así fue que se animó y desde entonces es socia, tiene como recuerdo que su primer crédito lo recibió cuando la moneda era en sucre.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank María Monserrate belongs to the city of Montecristi in the coastal province of Manabí.

Mrs. Cristina is married and has 4 children. She has been a street vendor for over 24 years; she sells scapulars, key rings, relics, candles and everything relating to catholic iconography. She also has a small business in her home. On Sundays, she sells her items outside of the Montecristi church. Besides selling her items during the festivities of other churches, Cristina travels and during the Christmas season she sells toys, costume jewelry (accessories for women) among other products.

Mrs. Cristina needs the money to expand her business; she travels to the city of Guayaquil to buy things like twine, slippers, and prints to decorate the rooms, a little bit of everything. With each purchase that she does, she spends between 800 and 1500 dollars, her husband and son help her with the business. She has been a member for some 24 years, she joined the bank because some foreigners came to motivate people of low income by letting them know that they could make loans with Espoir Foundation (Kiva’s field partner) and they could start their businesses. She tells us that these people gave them motivational talks and because of them she was encouraged and ever since then she has been a member. Mrs. Cristina remembers that her first loan she received was when the currency was in sucres.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy twine, slippers, and prints.

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es:
La señora Maria Elena M. B., tiene 44 años de edad, vende ropa y tiene una discomóvil, ella es casada y tiene una hija, ellos viven en el Barrio Laureles Norte.

Ella dice sentirse agradecida con los Fondos Kiva, por que poco a poco ha podido edificar su vivienda, ahora ella solicita para la compra de  ropa y para cubrir unos gastos y e invertir en el negocio, dentro de los problemas a los que se ha enfrentado, esta el desequilibro económico, por el cual atraviesa el país, pero no pierde las esperanzas, ni las fuerzas de trabajar duro y mejorar su estilo de vida y el de su familia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria Elena M. B. is 44 years old; she sells clothing and has a mobile disco/disc jockey service. She is married and has 1 daughter; they live in the Barrio Laureles Norte.

Maria is grateful to Kiva funds, because little by little she has been able to improve her home. Now she needs a loan to buy clothing, cover some expenses and to invest in the business. Some of the problems that she has faced are the economic problems that the country is going through, but she does not loose hope or the determination to keep working hard and to improve her way of life and that of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy used clothing.

loans.name: Enrique Tomas

texts.es:
