Mrs. Lai H. is 44 years old and she lives in Check village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a 2 hectare field to cultivate rice to earn a living. Her husband is a fisherman who earns a small income to support the family. 

Mrs. Lai H. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline to help her grow crops. She is the mother of three children: one is a farm laborer while the other two are students in the local school. Her husband is on the right in the picture.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Anhtuya

texts.en: Anhtuya B. is 37 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a ger. Her two children attend a local secondary school. Currently, Anhtuya operates a meat trading business with her husband at Huchit Shonhor, the most popular food market in Mongolia. She has been operating this business since 2000 and has expanded her business with a loyal customer base. Recently, in 2009, Anhtuya and her husband purchased their own plot of land. They have been planning to build a house with a yard on their own land. Anhtuya is a very hardworking person. She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to increase her working capital and to purchase timbers for a yard that will be built on her land.

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Huoy

texts.en: Mrs. Huoy K. is 50 years old and she lives in Vihear village in Kandal province. She is a grocery seller who can earn a small income to support her family. In order to increase her income to improve her family's lives, she wants to expand the business. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to enlarge her business. With this loan, she hopes to increase her income to improve her family's lives. Mrs. Huoy K. is a widow with three children. One of her children is a laborer and the other two are students in the local school and support their mother's business.

loans.use: To buy more groceries

loans.name: Alfredo

texts.en:
Alfredo T. is from the village of Brgy, which is in Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 33 years old. Alfredo is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Alfredo operates motorized tricycle transport services. Alfredo has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Alfredo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. He wanted to help improve his living situation and increase his ability to engage in business activities. Alfredo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. Alfredo is requesting a new loan in the anount of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase a new transport unit. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Alfredo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a new transport unit

loans.name: Chrin

texts.en: Mrs. Chrin S. was born in 1978 and now she lives in Trapeang Khlout village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer and she owns a small plot of land where she cultivates rice to earn an income. Her husband, Mr. Chear Yim, is a laborer. Even though they have different careers, they do not make enough money to support their living conditions. Therefore, Mrs. Chrin S. decided to ask for a loan to purchase two cows for breeding. She hopes to increase their income and improve their living situation with this loan. She is the mother of three children who are enrolled in the local public school. Her husband is on the right in the picture.

loans.use: To purchase two cows for breeding

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Zul

texts.en: Zul is 35 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a small house on a plot of land that belongs to his mother. During the day, he operates a meat trading business with his wife at the Huchit Shonhor, the most popular and crowded food market in Mongolia. He has been operating the business since 1995, and has steadily expanded the business and has become an experienced meat trader. He used a rental truck for his business until he purchased his own truck in 2007, which is helpful for saving transportation costs and increasing his profit. The meat trading business is one of the high profit businesses in Mongolia, and Zul's business is very important to him. He is requesting a 2,200,000-tugrug loan to increase his working capital.

loans.use: To increase his working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fertilizer, gasoline and pesticide

loans.name: Sovanna

texts.en: Mrs. Sovanna C. is 37 years old and she is a villager who lives in Peam Ta Aek village in Kandal province. She is a seamstress in the garment factory and she sells clothes to earn a living. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Sovanna C. decided to ask for a loan to buy more clothes to enlarge her business. With this loan, she hopes to increase her income to improve her living. Mrs. Sovanna C. is a widow without any children.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Sambath

texts.en: Mrs. Sambath O. is a villager in Trapeang Khlout village in Takeo province. She was born in 1954. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to grow rice to support her family. She is also a pig breeder. At present, she is a widow who lives with her four children. One of her children is a seamstress in a garment factory, two are laborers who take care of some ducks and earn a small salary, and one is attending a local public school. However they try to work hard, they can not support this family. Thus, Mrs. Sambath O. decided to ask for a loan to make more money to purchase a cow to breed.

loans.use: To purchase a cow to breed

loans.name: Ochirsuh

texts.en: Ochirsuh is 21 years old and lives with his wife in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He and his wife live in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a ger, on a plot of land that belongs to his mother. Presently, he operates a shoe trading business at Narantuul, the largest and most crowded market in Mongolia. Ochirsuh sells expensive high quality leather shoes at his counter. He purchases his products once a month from Beijing, the capital city of China. He has been planning to expand his business and to rent a counter in the shopping center. Ochirsuh is a very energetic and hard working person. He says, “I would like to purchase my own car, which will be helpful for my business.” Ochirsuh is requesting a 1,000,000-tugrug loan to expand his production line and purchase spring and autumn shoes to resell for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of shoes

loans.name: Thul

texts.en: Mr. Thul N. is married to Mrs. Chem Torn. They have a child who is attending the local public school. This family has three members who live in Trapeang Roka village in Takeo province. Mr. Thul N. is the village chief and his wife is a farmer who owns two hectares of land to grow vegetables and rice to sell to support her family. They have some problems because their field is far from an irrigation system and they do not have enough money to support the field. Thus, Mr. Thul N. decided to seek a loan to dig a well to produce rice and vegetables. With the rest of the loan, he would like to buy a water machine. Mr. Thul N. is busy with his work, so his wife came to take the loan instead of him.

loans.use: To dig a well

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Mrs. Touch S. is a villager in Trapeang Roka village in Takeo province. She was born in 1975. She and her husband, Mr. Nhor Ruos, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice to support their family. Through this activity, they try to work hard and earn a little money to support their four children. One of the children does farming with the parents and the others are attending the local public school. For this reason, they want to open a new business. Mrs. Touch S. decided to ask for a loan from AMK to buy a store and fruit for selling fruit. She hopes that she is going to earn a big income.

loans.use: To buy a store and fruit

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Thoeun N., 49 and his wife, Mrs. Pov Po (pictured together), 38, have been married since 1985 and have nine children: five sons and four daughters. Besides his children, he also has his mother living with him. They live in a small village along National Road Number Five about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Thoeun is a construction worker. He works in the nearby districts. He is asking for a loan of $300 to renovate the house where he lives.

loans.use: To renovate the house where he lives.

loans.name: Samnang

texts.en: Mrs. Samnang M., who is 26 years old, is a villager in Kdei Tnaot village in the Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land and cultivates rice to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Vet Sam, is a laborer in the local village. However hard they try to work, they cannot earn enough income. Thus, in order to improve their family's living conditions, Mrs. Samnang M. decided to request a loan to buy a pig and a cow for breeding. She is the mother of a child who is too small to work or study.

loans.use: To buy a mother pig, and a cow for breeding

loans.name: Non

texts.en:
Mrs. Non S. is 37 years old and she lives in Kdei Tnaot village in the Takeo Province. She breeds pigs at home and her husband, Mr. Yeng Chhoem, is a farmer who owns 2 hectares of land to cultivate rice for supporting his family. Aside from pig breeding, she is a palm juice collector who can earn some money for selling palm sugar. Through these activities, their living conditions are average, but they want to improve to a higher standard of living conditions. 

Mrs. Non S. decided to apply for a loan from AMK, a Kiva partner, to buy pig food and to build a pig stall for breeding pigs. This couple has three children, all of whom are attending a local public school.

loans.use: To buy pig food

loans.name: Nao

texts.en:
Mrs. Nao O., 45 (pictured with her son), and her husband, Mr. Tol Tep, 47, live in a small village along national road number 2 about 20 kilometers south of Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1983 and have three children: one son and two daughters. One of them works in a garment factory and the other two attend school. 

Nao has been a rice farmer since she was married, while her husband is a construction contractor. She is asking for a loan of $300 to purchase a water pumping machine. 

When the credit officers went to visit Nao’s family, they could only take Nao’s photo at home because the farm is a bit far away from her house.

loans.use: To purchase a water pumping machine

loans.name: Korb

texts.en: Mr. Korb C. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to support his family. Aside from this, he is a fisherman and his wife, Mrs. Sarun Korl, is a pig breeder in the local house. This couple has a child who is too young to go to school. Now a day, they are living in Kdei Tnaot village in Takeo Province. They have a problem because their field was ready to plow, but they did not plow. Thus, in order to improve the rice production, Mr. Korb C. decided to ask for a loan to buy two oxen to plow their field. His wife is on the left in the picture.

loans.use: To buy two oxen for plowing their field

loans.name: Naroeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Naroeun C. (pictured above), 37, and her husband, Mr. Ra Ket, 38, live in a small village across Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1996 and just have one young daughter.      

Naroeun has been a silk weaver for 20 years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. Her husband has been driving a motor taxi for 10 years. 

Naroeun is requesting her first loan of $350 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en:
Mr. Phalla Y., 43, and his wife, Mrs. Sa-em Pok, age 48, live in a small village off of National Road Number Two about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1995 and have two daughters. Both of their daughters attend school. Phalla was not in the photo but his wife was available instead. 

Phalla has full-time employment in Phnom Penh. His wife stays at home and does housework. He is requesting a loan of $1,000 to build a fence around his house and to build a kitchen.

loans.use: To build a fence and a kitchen.

loans.name: Benilda's Group

texts.en: Benilda Q.'s main source of income comes from raising pigs for breeding. She is 50 years old, married and has five school-age children. They are from the village of Jurisdiccion, Amulung, Cagayan. Benilda has been in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In ____, Benilda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Benilda has successfully repaid a previous loan of ____PHP from ASKI. She is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her fourth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. Benilda is the leader of a seven member group accessing a loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members, if someone is delinquent or defaults. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Poly

texts.en:
Mr. Poly H., 40 and his wife, Mrs. Amiros Sles, 38, were married in 1995 and have five children: three sons and two daughters. Four of them attend school and another one is still young. The family is living along National Road Number Six, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Poly and his wife have been selling goats and chickens for a year. They buy them from other provinces far away from their house and sell to a middleman who comes to buy at their house.  

Poly hopes to expand his business to become bigger and be able to generate income as well. So he is requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase additional goats for resale.

loans.use: To buy goats for resale.

loans.name: Elna

texts.en:
Elna M. is a 56-year-old married woman who lives in Brgy Poblacion, Sta. Catalina, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by buying and selling copras (dried coconut meat for coconut oil production)

Elna’s husband Juanito is a 56-year-old farmer. They have one child who already has a family. The couple is striving hard to sustain their family needs and are also preparing for their retirement.

Elna joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by buying and selling copras. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 10,000 from her business activities.

Elna is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of Php 3,000 was used to fund her operations of buying and selling copras, and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. She is now borrowing her 13th loan in the amount of Php 19,500. She will use the loan to buy and sell more copras. Elna is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy additional copras to resell

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a 67-year-old widowed woman who supports her family by running a general store and a cafeteria, and through pig fattening. She lives in Prk Ipil-Ipil Brgy Tabugon, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental, with her 8 children who are between 36 and 51 years old and all have their own families.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since May 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store, cafeteria, and pig fattening business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 10,000.

Gloria is now borrowing Php 19,500 so that she can continue sustaining operations of her general store, cafeteria and pig fattening businesses. This will be her 19th loan cycle with NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 19,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Gloria aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for her businesses

loans.name: Yoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Yoeun C. (pictured here), 32 and her husband, Mr. Hai Hok, have been married since 1993 and just have a young daughter. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Yoeun has been a garment factory worker for 10 years. Her husband has been selling piglets for four months. He buys piglets from the nearby districts and transports them to sell in other provinces.  

Yoeun is requesting her first loan of $1,200 to purchase more piglets for her husband to resell.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets

loans.name: Ganawathi

texts.en:
Ganawathi is a 54-year-old married woman with two children who lives in the town of Dickwella in southern Sri Lanka. Her husband works in the masonry business and her two sons, who are in their twenties, have jobs of their own as well.

Ganawathi has a small food production business, making local treats and foods to be sold to markets nearby. She has been in the business for about a year now.

Ganawathi is seeking a 30,000 LKR loan from BRAC to help purchase a new food-processing appliance.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy a new food-processing appliance

loans.name: Baykarimova Gulnora`s Group

texts.ru:
Гулнорахон 39 лет. Она замужем и мать 2 сыновей. Ее супруг работает строителем-отделщиком. Старший сын работает в сахарнопесочном цехе, а младший сын учится в школе. Она сама работает с учениками дошкольных классов и зарабатывает в месяц около 80 долларов. Кроме этого семья клиента занимается разведением и перепродажей КРС. КРедит запрашивается для закупа 2 голов КРС. 

Равшаной является родной сестрой Гулнорахон. Она также замужем и воспитывает 3 детей. Ее супруг работает бухгалтером в областном водном хозяйсте. Сама же работает в детском садике воспитателем. Ее вторая дочь поступает в ВУЗ в этом году и кредит будет использован для оплаты стоимости обучения. 

Гулчехрахон, 44, замужем. У нее 2 детей: сын и дочь. Дочь учится в медицинском училище, а сын учится на 11 классе средней школы. Супруг работает начальником кислородного цеха. Гулчехра вместе с Равшаной работает в одном детском садике. Дома у них есть маленькое хозяйство по откорму живности. Кредит запрашивается для закупа 2 телок. 

Мухтарам, 48, замужем. Ее супруг работает в Бишкеке частным таксистом. Мухтарам также воспитатель детского садика. Кредит запрашивается для закупа 1 бычка для последующего откорма. 

Все они уже получают второй кредит, достаточно хорошо знают друг друга и всецело поддерживают. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Gulnorahon is 39 years old. She is married and is a mother of two sons. Her husband works as a construction worker. Her older son works in a factory for making of sugar and her younger son goes to school. She works with pre-school children and makes around $80US a month. Besides that the family does agriculture and breeding and resale of large cattle. The are asking for the loan to buy two heads of cattle. Ravshanoy is a sister of Gulnorahon. She is also married and has three children. Her husband works as an accountant in the regional water reservoir. She works in the kindergarten as a caretaker. Her second daughter is entering a university this year and the loan will be used to pay for the tuition. Gulchehrahon is 44 years old, she is married. She has two children, a son and a daughter. Her daughter is studying in a medical school and her son is in the eleventh grade of a secondary school (high school). Her husband works as a director of an oxygen factory. Gulchehra together with Ravshanoy work in the same kindergarten. At home they have a small business breeding livestock. The loan will be used to buy two calves. Muhtaram is 48, she is married. Her husband works in Bishkek as a taxi driver. Muhtaram is also a caretaker in the kindergarten. She is asking for the loan to buy one calf for feeding. All of them are taking out a second loan, they know each other very well and all support one another.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy two calves

loans.name: Bunna

texts.en:
Mr. Bunna N. (pictured with his wife), age 29, and his wife, Mrs. Sumtheary Seng, age 30, live in a small village across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 2005 and have a young daughter.  

Bunna has been selling rice for a year. His wife stays at home and does housework. He hopes to expand his business and be able to generate more income as well. That’s why he is asking for his first loan of $1,200 to purchase more rice for resale.

loans.use: To purchase rice for resale

loans.name: Thon

texts.en:
Mrs. Thon Y. (pictured with her daughter) is a widow with two daughters. One of her daughters is a garment-factory worker. She also has her elderly mother living with her. They live along National Road Number 5 about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Thon has been selling porridge for seven years. She wants to buy a cow to raise. She will earn additional income from selling the cow when it grows big enough. Therefore, she is asking for her first loan of $400 to make the purchase.

loans.use: To purchase a cow to raise

loans.name: Vasati

texts.en:
Vasati P. is 45 and married with 4 children (ages 5 - 12).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Vasati has 2 years of experience in this business.  Vasati needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 350 talas or US $146 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Vasati joined SPBD.    This is her 1st loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Vasati's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.
http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Piniki

texts.en:
Piniki L. is 26 and married with 1 child (2 years-old).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Piniki has 3 years of experience in this business.  Piniki needs a loan of WST $1500 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or US $188 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2008, Piniki joined SPBD.  This is her 2nd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Piniki's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Piniki L. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.3 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.4 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.5 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              1.5 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Ailima

texts.en:
Ailima M. is 45 and married with 4 children.  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Ailima has many years of experience in this business.  Ailima needs a loan of WST $1500 to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve/expand the business.  Ailima wishes to extend her business as she applies for another fund to assist her development.

Ailima joined SPBD.  This is her 4th loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Ailima's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Kaiva

texts.en:
Kaiva G. is 50 and married with 5 children.  She owns a business venture, catching & selling ocean-caught fish .  Kaiva has 3 years of experience in this business.  Kaiva needs a loan of WST $1700 to purchase a fishing boat.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Kaiva joined SPBD.This is her 4th loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Kaiva's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Kaiva G. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.6 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase a fishing boat

loans.name: Veronika

texts.en:
Veronika L. is 55 and married with 6 children (ages 9 - 18).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Veronika has many years of experience in this business.  Veronika needs a loan of WST $3000 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2005, Veronika joined SPBD.  This is her 5th loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Veronika's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Veronika L. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.5 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.4 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.5 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              1.6 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Perpetua

texts.en: Perpetua E. joined ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap Inc.), a Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2005. Since then, she has grown to love the organization. ASHI helped her in the start-up of a business, supporting her husband with their daily expenditures. She and her husband have been direct selling Avon products for more than five years and also embarked in buying and selling dried fish in the local community. She now proposes that her eighth loan, amounting to 45,000.00 Philippine pesos, be used to continue her businesses with the support of her husband. She will purchase inventory of supplies like cologne, body lotion, lipstick, sandals, shoes, perfumes, jackets and other stock. The remaining loan funds will be used for her dried-fish business for additional income. Expanding Perpetua’s business will be the source of income to finance the needs of her family and to have a comfortable house to live in. She also hopes to expand her business and if possible, have a branch in other provinces, particularly in her hometown in order to provide employment to her relatives. She is very thankful to all members of ASHI for educating her, especially in dealing with other people and the ability to accept new challenges in her life and in achieving her dreams to improve their way of life. Perpetua is also grateful to the ASHI-Kiva partnership for supporting people like her who want to move away from poverty and get ahead. She hopes that they continue this way for a long time and help many poor families. The couple has a strong belief not to be affected by poverty; instead they are inspired to work hard for their five children. About ASHI As a micro-finance institution that uses the Grameen methodology, Ahon sa Hirap (ASHI), being the first practitioner in the field, saw how poor women and mothers work hard to earn money for the cash flow of their families and to provide their children with a better life. The micro-credit ASHI is extending to these women is delivered directly to their villages and on the doorstep of their houses. When the loan is handed over to them, it is giving them hope that someday they will rise above poverty. (“Rise above poverty” is a direct English translation of “Ahon sa Hirap.”)

loans.use: To purchase inventory of cologne, body lotion, lipstick, sandals, shoes, perfumes, jackets, etc., and to support her dried fish business

loans.name: Julita

texts.en: A proud member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, since 2003, Julita has been a dedicated member demonstrating regular attendance to weekly center meetings and solid repayments on previous loans. She is grateful to the ASHI-Kiva partnership for support of all of her dreams and the challenges in life. Julita is 65 years old. Her husband, Darico, is a farmer and works closely with her. To have a stable income for her family, Julita has been running a farming business for almost 10 years. Julita would like to obtain a loan amounting to 20,000 Philippine pesos to purchase additional materials for her business, including palay (rice seeds), insecticides, other supplies and labor expenses. Julita believes that the loan will help to grow her farming business and drive increased revenue. Her dreams are to maintain the productivity of her business and to build a concrete and durable home. Julita is hopeful that her farming business ventures will continue to grow and improve her overall standard of living and help her move away from the umbrella of poverty. About ASHI Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of the Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the most poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: To purchase additional materials for her business, including palay (rice seeds), insecticides, other supplies and labor expenses.

loans.name: Abdullo

texts.ru: Рахимов Абдулло проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 39 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Абдулло более 18 лет занимается торговлей. Он в основном продает фрукты на рынке. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Abdullo R. lives in the town of Tursun-zoda. He is 39 years old. He is married and has five children. His wife is a homemaker. Abdullo has been in the sales business for more than eighteen years. He mainly sells fruits on the market. He is taking out a loan to increase sales.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase sales volume

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
With her belief and faith in coming out from under the umbrella of poverty, Josefina decided to join Kiva partner, ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.), in 2000. It provided her with an opportunity of accessing start-up capital for income-generating activities. With her first loan from ASHI, she carefully invested in her sari-sari store (a small retail store selling different goods). She uses the profits for daily expenses.
Now on her third loan, Josefina is requesting 15,000 PHP to create a broader business. Specifically, the amount will be used to purchase additional supplies for her sari-sari store, such as cases of beers, soft drinks, and other stocks. She is very determined and disciplined in her use of the loan.
Josefina still dreams of the best for her family: to provide the best education for her grandchildren and to have a happy family. During the course of her membership in ASHI, she has shown herself to be industrious and determined to make her dreams come true.
Josefina is a 54-year-old business-minded woman. Her husband passed away so she is now the single mother of her daughter, Janett. She lives in Pililia, in the province of Rizal, Philippines. She belongs to a poor family that needs help to improve its standard of living and she is grateful to ASHI for support in all the challenges of life.

About ASHI
Ahon sa Hirap Inc., or ASHI, has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of Grameen methodology to credit delivery to the bottom poor in the Philippines. ASHI, as the first practitioner in the field, saw how poor women and mothers worked hard to earn money for their family and provide their children with a better life. Since the microcredit ASHI is extending to these women is delivered directly in their villages on the doorsteps of their houses, they are given the hope that someday they will “rise above poverty” (a translation of Ahon Sa Hirap, in English.)

loans.use: To purchase cases of beers, soft drinks, and other stocks

loans.name: Veronilla

texts.en:
Veronilla M. is a 40-year-old married woman who lives in the green farm country of the Rizal province town of Pililia. She has three children, one of whom is a high school student, while the others are at elementary school. Over the years she has provided for her family by hog-raising, including slaughtering, and by buying and selling different small goods in her village.
Veronilla’s biggest dream is to have a successful pig farm someday. She believes this opportunity will give her the confidence to succeed while helping her family rise out of poverty. The financial opportunity of hog-fattening is one of the best ways to help provide for her family and she very much wants to lift her family out of scarcity.
This loan of 10,000 PHP is for hog-fattening, a common business for people in her area who are afflicted with poverty. Veronilla will buy small piglets, sacks of feed, and supplements and vitamins for the piglets. She will raise them for approximately four to six months until they are ready for sale. Her long-term goals are to build a sustainable business, fund her children’s college education, and construct a more durable home that can survive flooding, which is common in her town. With the support of ASHI and Kiva, she is hopeful that her hog-fattening business will generate a steady income to improve her financial stability and her family’s quality of life.

About ASHI
Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of the Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the bottom poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: To buy small piglets, sacks of feeds, and supplements and vitamins for the piglets

loans.name: Rustam

texts.ru: Уринов Рустам проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 56 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Образование высшее "Бухгалтер". Работает по профессии. Кроме того занимается растениеводством. Имеет земельный участок, где сажает пшеницу. В этой областе более 8 лет. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений. Рустам хочет посеить и получить хороший урожай.
texts.en:
Rustam U. lives in the town of Turzun-zoda. He is 56 years old. He is married and has four children. He has a degree in accounting and works in his profession. Besides his work he does agriculture. He has a plot of land where he plants wheat. He has been in this business for more than eight years. The loan will be used for purchase of mineral fertilizer. Rustam wants to sow and collect a good harvest.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Joram

texts.en:
At 65 years old, Joram has six grown children and now a four-year-old grandchild. He started farming ten years ago when he retired after many years of employment. His farm is in Ndikwe, near Murang'a, in the Central Province of Kenya. He sells the bananas, milk, and maize from his farm in the local market. He also earns income from his posho mill (pictured with Joram above) by charging other farmers a fee to grind cereals, mostly maize, into flour. The main challenge to his business is a lack of funding for farming inputs such as seeds and manure. Recently, there has also been a poor market for farm produce.
Joram is the chairman of his solidarity group at Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, and completed a previous individual loan for 30,000 KES. He has requested a new individual loan for 75,000 KES to make improvements to his posho mill and expand his dairy farm by buying and insuring a new dairy cow. He aims to improve his income by producing up to 20 liters of milk a day and increase his customer base by offering a better service because he will be able to handle larger quantities of cereals.
Joram says that Juhudi Kilimo has enabled him to get back into the posho mill business and make improvements. He has also been able to acquire a dairy cow and a goat.

loans.use: To buy a cow and improve his posho mill

loans.name: Cyrus

texts.en:
Cyrus has a farm with mixed crops near Murang'a in the Central Province of Kenya. He is 32 years old and has already been farming for eleven years. He grows cash crops, like tea and coffee, and horticultural crops. He is also a dairy farmer and sells his milk through the local Kenya Cooperative Creamery. The challenges to his business are lack of funding, the expensive price of animal feeds, and a poor market for milk.
Cyrus has successfully repaid a previous loan from Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, for 60,250 KES and is requesting a new loan for 47,700 KES to buy and insure an additional dairy cow. He hopes that with this loan he can improve his income enough to move from his parents' house and build his own home for his young family. In the future, he plans to have as many as five cows and produce more than 50 liters of milk.
He says that Juhudi Kilimo has improved his life with its financial help and good credit terms. He feels that his dreams can be realized only through Juhudi Kilimo's credit facilities so he is "here to stay".

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her pig-farming business

loans.name: Arthur

texts.en:
Arthur is a 44-year-old farmer and a married father of three children, aged 11, 15, and 16 years. He lives near Murang'a in the Central Province of Kenya. Arthur cultivates a mixed crop and is also a dairy farmer, selling his milk to the Wanjengi Dairy. He has been farming for 20 years but also earns some extra income as a carpenter. The challenge to his business is managing fluctuations in price and demand in the milk market.
Arthur successfully repaid a previous loan from Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, for 25,000 KES. He has requested a new loan of 31,800 KES to buy and insure a dairy cow. He says that Juhudi Kilimo is doing an incredible job of helping low-income farmers to acquire assets. With the additional income he will earn from the new dairy cow, he believes he will be able to pay for his children's education.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her poultry business

loans.name: Merab Atieno

texts.en:
Merab Atieno O. is 50 years old. She is married with six children and lives in Nyalenda, Kisumu, Kenya. Merab was a housewife depending fully on her husband’s meager earnings until 1990 when she began selling fish. She now also does tailoring. A determined and hardworking woman, Merab goes as far as Busia to purchase her tailoring materials on a weekly basis.
Merab would like to expand her business in order to earn enough income to open a community-based organization (CBO) to support widows, orphans and vulnerable children (OVCs) and also people living with HIV-AIDS (PLWHAS). She is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to increase her material stock.

loans.use: To increase her stock of clothing materials

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Peris

texts.en:
Peris is a 65-year-old mother of four who has been farming for 44 years. She has a mixed farm near Murang'a, in the Central Province of Kenya, and is also a dairy farmer. She sells cereals locally and, for extra income, she runs a small shop and rents out property. Through these endeavors, she is able to employ three people in the community. The challenge to her businesses is a lack of income for expansion and competition from other similar businesses.
Peris has requested her first loan of 53,000 KES from Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, to buy and insure an additional dairy cow. The extra income from the milk will allow her to complete her ongoing construction projects and, in the future, she will be able to produce about 30 liters a day and expand into poultry farming. She says Juhudi Kilimo is really helping low-income farmers unlike other financial institutions.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a 32-year-old farmer and married father of two young children, aged seven and ten. He has been farming a mixed crop for the last ten years and also runs a small shop. He earns income selling stones and the cereals produced on his farm. The greatest challenge to his business ventures is a lack of capital to expand. 

John has requested his first loan of 45,000 KES from Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, to begin poultry farming. With this new venture, he will be able to meet demand for eggs within the local area. In the future, he would also like to expand into dairy farming and open an Agrovet shop. John commented that, "Juhudi Kilimo is supporting more low-income farmers than other microfinance institutions" and that because of their support he will be able to diversify his business.

loans.use: To start a poultry business

loans.name: Shakilah

texts.en:
Shakilah, aged 34 years, is the mother of four. She currently lives in a family house with a dream to build her personal residential house.

Shakilah owns a lubricants shop in Hoima, Uganda which she has now operated for 10 years. She has come along way in business from charging batteries to selling produce and finally setting up a lubricants shop using savings and credit facilities from Hofokam. She is taking it step by step, seeing her business grow.

The purpose of the loan is to purchase oil and filters and also to clear her farmland for planting.

loans.use: To purchase more oil and filters to sell and to clear her farmland for planting

loans.name: Sayfullo

texts.ru: Джураев Сайфулло проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 42 года. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Сайфулло имеет средне- специальное образование. Работает зав. складом. Кроме того занимается растениеводством. Сажает пшеницу и получив урожай вывозит на рынок. Этой деятельностью занимается уже 9 лет. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
Sayfullo J. lives in the town of Tursun-zoda. He is 42 years old. He is married and has five children. His wife is a homemaker. Sayfullo has a specialized secondary education and works as a manager of a warehouse. He also does agriculture. He plants wheat and sells the collected harvest on the market. He has been in this business for nine years. He is taking out the loan to buy mineral fertilizer.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Ret

texts.en:
Mr. Ret T. (pictured above) and his wife, Mrs. Nun Chheng, live along National Road Number One, about 35 kilometers from Phnom Penh. The couple was married in 1965 and has five children: three sons and two daughters. Four of them are married and live outside the family home and the other works in a garment factory.
Ret and his wife are farmers. They grow rice on their farmland in the village, and hope to continue the business as it is their main way of supporting their standard of living. Therefore, Ret is requesting a loan of $600 USD to purchase fertilizer, seed and pesticides to maintain his rice farm.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, seed and pesticides

loans.name: Geoffrey

texts.en:
Geoffrey is a 28-year-old man living in Hoima, Uganda. His wife owns a drug shop and they live together with their one year old child. Together with his wife, they both contribute to the family welfare.

Geoffrey started working in a bakery then rode his sister-in-law’s motorcycle for hire, after which he used his small savings and a loan from HOFOKAM to buy his own motorcycle.

Geoffrey’s business plan for the loan is to buy a new motorcycle for his business.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle for his business

loans.name: Man

texts.en:
Mr. Man M. (pictured above) and his wife, Mrs. Amminas Man, were married in 1980 and have five children: three sons and two daughters. Two of their children are married and live in separate homes while the other three children attend school. The family lives on National Road Number 6, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.
Man has been a fisherman for more than 15 years. He catches fish from the Mekong River near his village. Mrs Amminas Man sells the fish her husband catches to the villagers. Man has had a Kiva loan once before. He hopes to continue increasing the volume of fish he catches in order to generate more income. Therefore, he is applying for his second loan of $300 USD to purchase additional fishing materials.

loans.use: To buy additional fishing materials

loans.name: Lilian Akinyi

texts.en:
Lilian Akinyi O. is 27 years old, married, and the mother of one child. After quitting her house help job, Lilian decided to venture into business selling vegetables in Nyalenda, Kisumu, Kenya. She started her business in 2006 to generate income and support her husband in providing for the family.
Lilian dreams of expanding her trade so that she is able to buy a car for her business. For this reason, she decided to join the microfinance program of Kiva partner, K-MET, to expand her business knowledge. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to increase her stock, with the hope of seeing her income grow. With her new profits, she hopes to build her own home, but this does not mean that her dream of buying a car has disappeared!

loans.use: To increase her stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroeun L. (shown in the photo) and her husband, Heng Min, live on an island in the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Married in 1979, they have five children, two sons and three daughters. Two of her daughters, who are both, silk weavers, were married but live inside the family home. Another daughter is learning the skill of tailoring, one son is a teacher and the other attends school.

Saroeun is a silk weaver, while her husband raises cows at home. Saroeun already asked Kiva for one loan. She now is applying for another loan of $250 to purchase silk materials to continue her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials to continue her silk waving business.

loans.name: Caren

texts.en:
Caren A. is a 50 year old widow with three children to care for. She has a weaving business where she makes and sells mats. She started this business in the year 2000 in Dunga Kisumu, Kenya after giving up selling vegetables as her only source of income to provide the school fees for her children and other basic needs.

She wishes to get a loan worth KSH 20,000 to be able to increase her stock as she intends to expand her business. Her dream is to build her own house and provide her children with a better education so that they can have a bright future.

loans.use: Increase her stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en: Melanie A. owns and operates a specialized retail store selling personal use products such as body sprays, talc powder, lotions and makeup in her community. She is 34 years old, married and has two school-age children. They are from the city of San Fermin, Cauayan City, Isabela. Melanie has been in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 12,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Melanie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Melanie is requesting a loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to pay the tuition fees of her children. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Lay

texts.en:
Mrs. Lay U. (pictured above) and her husband, Mr. Thorn Uk, live in a small village across the Mekong River and about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1983 and have five children, three sons and two daughters. One of her sons is an electrician, three are in school and another one is still young.

Lay has been a silk weaver for more than twenty-nine years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a house builder for more than nineteen years.

Lay has asked for a Kiva loan several times already. She is now applying for another loan of $700 to purchase silk materials to continue her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials to continue her weaving business.

loans.name: Bekmurod

texts.ru: Кобилов Бекмурод проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 26 лет. Женат, имеет одного ребенка. Образование высшее "Педогог". Преподает в средней школе. Одновременно занимается растениеводством. Арендует небольшой земельный участок, где выращивает овощи. Этой деятельностью занимается более 5 лет. Кредит берет для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
Bekmurod K. lives in the region of Shahrituz. He is 26 years old. He is married and has one child. He has a higher education as a teacher and teaches in a secondary school. He does agriculture at the same time. He rents a small plot of land where he grows vegetables. He has been doing this business for more than five years. He is taking out a loan to buy seeds and mineral fertilizer.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seeds and mineral fertlizer

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthy H. and her husband, Mr. Phalla Mok, 42, were married in 1990 and have three children: two sons and one daughter, all of whom attend school. They live along National Road Number Five about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia.

Chanthy has been a tailor for more than five years, while her husband is a rice farmer. By the way, one of her sons just finished his baccalaureate and continues his studying at University in Phnom Penh as well. He is a first year student of IT (Information Technology).

Chanthy hopes to support her children’s further education so that they will have good jobs when they finish their studying. So she is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase a computer for her son.

loans.use: To purchase a computer for her son

loans.name: Caren Akoth

texts.en:
Caren Akoth O. farms vegetables which she later sells to consumers and to other retailers. She started this business in 2006 as an income generator since she was tired of staying home as a housewife. She is 27 years old, married with four children, and lives in Nyamasaria, Kisumu, Kenya.

Caren would like to enlarge her farm so that she can do her farming on a larger scale. This will attract more customers and hence earn more income to enable her to support her children’s education. She would like to obtain a loan of Ksh 10,000

loans.use: To enlarge her farm

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Laarnie's Group

texts.en: Laarnie G.'s main source of income comes from butchering and selling a variety of meats in her community. She is 28 years old, married and has one small child. They are from the village of Larion Bajo, Tuguegarao City. Laarnie has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 9,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. Laarnie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. Laarnie is the leader of a 12 member group accessing a loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sokheng

texts.en: Mrs. Sokheng K. and her husband, Mr. Phally Chlam, have been married for more than a year and just have a young daughter. They live in a small village across the Mekong River about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Sokheng has been a silk weaver for more than five years. When she is free, whe also assists her husband in his business raising chickens. Sokheng has obtained one Kiva loan already. She now is now requesting another loan of US$500 to put an addition on her house and to build a fence around it.

loans.use: To put an addition on her house and to build a fence around it

loans.name: Monalisa

texts.en:
Monalisa N. is from the city of San Isidro, Tarlac. She is 36 years old. Monalisa is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Monalisa runs a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling fish and seafood products in the local community. Monalisa has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Monalisa joined ASKI this year to gain access to financial services. She wished to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Monalisa is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Monalisa from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish and seafood products to sell

loans.name: Phoem

texts.en:
Mr. Phoem P., 50, and his wife, Mrs. Sros Kong, 48, (pictured together) live in a small village in a suburb of Phnom Penh. They have five children: two sons and three daughters, two of whom are married and live outside the family home, one is a garment factory worker and the other two have full-time employment.

Phoem has been driving a motorcycle taxi for ten years while his wife runs a grocery store at their house. Phoem is asking for a loan of $500 to repair their house.

loans.use: To repair his house

loans.name: Mallika

texts.en:
Mallika is a 55-year-old woman living with her husband and two children in the town of Dickwella, Sri Lanka.

Mallika has a business growing bananas, which she runs with her husband, and they have done this for a long time now. The household is entirely dependent on their income from banana cultivation. Over the years, Mallika has developed a good knowledge of agriculture, and considers herself to be an innocent and honest lady.

Mallika is seeking a 50,000 LKR loan from BRAC to expand her enterprise. In fact, this will be Mallika's 3rd loan with BRAC, as she has successfully received and repaid loans in the past. In the future, Mallika and her husband hope to be able to provide employment to another person in the community through the expansion of their business.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To purchase agricultural products to aid her banana cultivation

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
Fred is the head of a family with four children aged thirteen, ten, eight, and four. He is a carpenter in Karuguuza, Uganda and his wife is a health worker. He has been in the carpentry and joinery business for the last fifteen years and he has been able to construct a commercial house from the profits gained. 

Fred has been a Hofokam client for two years. Having first worked as a technical teacher, he later opened a carpentry workshop in rented premises but now operates it in his own commercial house. The purpose of the loan is buy more mahogany timber to enable him to produce quality work.

loans.use: buying  more mahogany timber

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph owns an electrical appliances shop in Karuguuza, Uganda managed by his wife with whom he has three children aged six, three, and eight months. He has operated his shop for three years now and has seen it grow steadily with good, considerable profit.

Joseph is a civil servant with the local government. He dreams of being the supplier of electrical appliances in Karuguuza town as a wholesaler. He plans to use the loan from Hofokam to purchase electrical wire, kettles and flat irons for resale, items which he says have the biggest demand.

loans.use: purchase electrical wires, kettles and flat irons for reselling

loans.name: Andrei

texts.en:
Andrei is single. He owns a small business selling various home products: electric appliances, kitchen goods and other items. Andrei has been in this business for 11 years. His income is about 6,000 hryvnia (UAH) per month.

Andrei's little store is located in the central market. The good location and good prices bring in many customers. Andrei is a very responsible and disciplined person. He has used business loans before and always paid them back on time. This time, Andrei is requesting a loan of 9,700 UAH to purchase additional inventory. He hopes to increase sales and to develop his business further.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Anor

texts.ru: Алимова Анор проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 50 лет. Замужем, имеет 5 детей. Образование среднее. Более 15 лет занимается растениеводством. Она в основном выращивает овощи. В этой деятельности ей помогает муж. Кредит берет для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
Anor A. lives in the Shahrituz district. She is 50 years old, married and has 5 children. She has a secondary education. Anor has been involved in agriculture for over 15 years. She primarily grows vegetables. Her husband helps her with this business. Anor is requesting the loan for the purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Hidir

texts.ru: Хидиров Хидир проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст 42 года. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Хидир более 10 лет занимается растениеводством. При доме имеет участок земли, где зажает пшеницу и кортофель. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
Hidir H. lives in the Shahrituz district. He is 42 years old, married and has 2 children. His wife is a homemaker. Hidir has been involved in agriculture for over 10 years. He has a plot of land by his house, where he grows wheat and potatoes. Hidir is requesting the loan for the purchase of mineral fertilizers.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of mineral fertilizers

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Silvia

texts.en:
Silvia is a single mother, raising her child by herself. She sells clothing at a bus station in the small town of Svalyava, Western Ukraine. Silvia has been in this business for six years. This business is the only source of income for her family.

Silvia would like to borrow 9,500 hryvnia (UAH) to increase her assortment. She hopes to increase sales and make additional income. Silvia is a very active person and has the desire to develop her business further.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of clothing

loans.name: Anna

texts.en: Anna M. is a married woman and an entrepreneur. She runs a poultry business in Yombo Dovya ward in Dar es Salaam. She keeps both broilers and layers in her poultry cage units. She collects 40 trays of eggs per day and sells retail and wholesale to customers for domestic consumption and businesses. She has been in the business for six years. She managed to construct five poultry units from her business income. She needs a loan of 1,200,000 Tanzanian shillings to capitalize the business.

loans.use: To capitalize a poultry business

loans.name: Voicy

texts.en:
Voicy J., currently in the business of selling various items in her shop such as soap, biscuits, washing powder, etc., is requesting a loan to stock more goods. Voicy is 32 years old and married to a businessman. They have two children, both in school. With the extra profits from her loan, Voicy hopes to be able to invest in an expansion of the shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more goods in her shop

loans.name: Lona

texts.en:
Lona S. is currently in the business of selling groundnut phase and charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes and beans to sell. Lona, 29, and her husband, who is a driver, have four children, all of whom go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to establish a charcoal store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock tomatoes and beans to sell

loans.name: Kulwa

texts.en:
Kulwa H. is a married entrepreneur. She runs a business supplying meat to butchery businesses in Yombo Makangarawe ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases her business goods in wholesale from the animal slaughtering center and supplies them to customers by order. She owns one meat supply pick-up car.
Kulwa's business income allows her to meet her family's daily needs and put capital into her business. She is requesting a loan of 1,200,000 TZS to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity A. is 28 years old and married to a peasant. She has two school-aged children. Charity is currently in the business of selling onions, tomatoes and dried fish at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock Irish potatoes and dried cassava tubers. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to buy a fridge for home use.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock Irish potatoes and dried cassava tubers

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en:
Hadija A. is a married small businesswoman. She runs a fruit and green vegetable shop in Vingunguti ward, Dar es Salaam. She purchases and sells different varieties of fruits and green vegetables to customers. She purchases fruit from the Buguruni fruit market center wholesale and sells retail to consumers. Green vegetables are purchased directly from the producers. 

The business income helps her so much to meet her family's daily demands and to capitalize the business. Hadija A. needs a loan of 700,000 Tanzanian shillings to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Shomurod

texts.ru: Пармонов Шомурод проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 46 лет. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Имеет среднее образование. Занимается растениеводством. Он в основном выращивает овощи. В этой области уже 10 лет. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
Shomurod P. lives in the Shahrituz district. He is 46 years old, married and has 6 children. His wife is a homemaker. He has a secondary education and is involved in agriculture. Shomurod primarily grows vegetables. He has been in this business for 10 years. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of mineral fertilizers.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en: Joshua A. B. is thirty-one years old. He and his wife have one sixteen-month-old child. His wife sells curtains and hand bags.  They hope to give their child a good education, up to the university level. Joshua's business is located in Kakamega. He sells sugar, flour, and soft drinks to the local people. He has been doing this business for the last six years. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is that there are very many people engaged in the same business as his, so customers are spoilt for choice. He works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of KES 40,000 to buy more bags of sugar, crates of soda, milk and other goods that he sells, to grow his business. He hopes to become a wholesaler in the future. He is very hardworking and honest.

loans.use: To buy sugar, crates of soda, milk, etc.

loans.name: Batjargal

texts.en: Batjargal is 32 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a ger. Presently, he operates a machinery and spare parts trading business in his hometown. Batjargal sells a variety of machinery parts in his two shipping containers at a local market. He has been operating this business since 2001 and has steadily expanded his business. Originally, he was a herder and owned a few heads of livestock in a remote area of his home province before he moved to the center of the Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. Batjargal has been planning to expand his production line by purchasing Korean machinery parts and reselling them for a profit. He has gained much experience in the previous nine years and his business is very important to him. Batjargal is a very hardworking person and he has many plans for the future. He says, “I would like to expand my business in the future.” He is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug loan to increase the working capital of his business.

loans.use: To increase his capital

loans.name: Sumbua

texts.en:
Sumbua B. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and onions at the market and is requesting a loan to stock cooking oil and charcoal to sell. Sumbua is 20 years old and is married to a driver. She has two children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock cooking oil and charcoal to sell

loans.name: Kelen

texts.en:
Kelen is a 71-year-old widow with three children. She runs a mixed farm in Kenya, near the town of Murang'a, where she has been farming for over 40 years. With the help of one employee, she grows a variety of produce, which she sells locally.
Kelen is a new client of Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo. She has requested a loan of 35,720 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. In addition, she has enrolled in a Juhudi Kilimo and C.I.C. Insurance health-care program, which will cover any of her personal medical expenses. Overall, Kelen is optimistic now as she is able to use her loan to purchase a dairy cow for personal milk consumption and sell the surplus.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Oleg

texts.en:
Oleg is married and has two teenage daughters. He sells bicycles, spare parts, and other cycle supplies at the hardware market in Berdyansk. He has been in this business for 13 years and just likes selling bicycles. Besides good products, Oleg offers his customers bicycle maintenance services. People value this kind of service and recommend Oleg to their friends.
Oleg has used business loans before and finds them instrumental in developing his business. Prompt loan repayment and self-discipline have characterized Oleg in the past. This time, Oleg is requesting a loan of 20,000 UAH to increase his inventory of bicycles and various components. Financial assistance will continue to promote the growth of his business and give many bike-lovers the extra moments of joy, speed and adventure that come with riding.

loans.use: To purchase bicycles and components for resale

loans.name: Alicia's Group
