loans.use: Remodeling beauty salon

loans.name: Yalama-Yalama Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Yalama-Yalama sont essentiellement des  femmes mariées  ayant en moyenne 40 ans, 5 enfants et  vivant dans des familles monogames à Noumousso, un des quartiers de la ville de Kadiolo, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur cinquième  prêt solidaire.
Tous les prêts précédents  ont été bien remboursés. 
Elles font la vente d’huile, de pagnes wax, de pommades cosmétiques et de la restauration.
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 4 bidons d’huile de 20litres, 6 pièces de pagnes wax, 4 cartons de pommades cosmétiques, 1sac de 100kg de riz, 3 paquets de condiments alimentaires, 1sac de 75kg d’haricots. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Kadiolo ville et dans les villages avoisinants. Elles vendent au marché, à domicile et de façon ambulante au comptant  souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 30.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille,  l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités
texts.en:
The members of the group Yalama-Yalama are essentially married women averaging 40 years of age and five children each living in monogamous families in Noumousso, a district of Kadiolo City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The group members are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy the needs of their customers.  They are now on their fifth solidarity loan.  All the preceding loans have been repaid. The group members sell oil, wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), and cosmetic ointments, and they work in food catering.  With their new loan, they intend to buy four 20-liter containers of oil, six bolts of pagnes, a 100-kg sack of rice, three packets of condiments, and a 75-kg sack of beans.  Supplies are gotten at the big market of Kadiolo City and from neighboring villages. Sales are made at the market, out of the home, and by going door-to-door.  Cash and often credit is accepted from customers composed of men and women.  The group members each envision making a monthly profit of 30,500 francs CFA.  A portion of the profits will be put into savings and used for family needs.  The other part will be invested in the businesses. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase his inventory

loans.name: Carren

texts.en: Carren is 41 and a widow with seven children. She lives in Likoni but is originally from Nyanza province. Carren sells decovents which are used for installing ventilation in buildings — a business mostly dominated by men. She says this is more profitable than her previous business selling second hand clothes. She gets her materials for making the decovents from local hardware vendors and requires Kshs 30,000 to increase her supply of cement and the other materials she needs.

loans.use: Buy materials

loans.name: Yuos

texts.en:
Yuos T., age 55, cultivates a variety of crops on farmland that was inherited from her grandparents. She has financial support in her husband, who is a village advisor. For years, they have owned a medium-sized house located in a rural area of Phnom Penh, where they live with their family. The couple has given birth to nine children, six of whom are now married. 

Yuos T. has made an income through her farming work in order to feed their children from the time they were young. Yuos T. has requested a loan in order to purchase a farming machine to supply her farming business. She plans to rent her new machine to other farmers for a fee.

(Mrs. Yuos T. was not available for photographing so her husband is pictured instead.)

loans.use: To purchase a farming machine

loans.name: Tohir

texts.en:
Tohir is an enterprising man, active and very hardworking. He has always wanted to have his own business and he made this happen 13 years ago when he started up his own business selling flour, sugar, oil and vegetables. He is married and has seven children. This business, apart from being his dream, is the way Tohir can earn a living for his family and educate his children. Starting wasn’t easy, but with his and his family’s hard work, they have been able to get ahead. Tohir has put all of his effort into making his business grow. He is just missing one little push, which is why he needs a loan of 4500 Somoni, which he will use to buy merchandise to stock his store. With this, he hopes to offer a wider variety and better service to his customers, which is how he hopes to ensure that they will prefer his store. This will help him grow as a small business owner. You can be an important part of the development of this store. You can support Tohir and his family. With your help, he can do great things.   


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more goods to sell

loans.name: Allakademe Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe  Allakademe sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  ayant  une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans,  5 enfants et  vivant à égalité dans des familles polygames et monogames à Hamdallaye  un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles font la vente de pâte d’arachide, de légumes, d’oranges et d’encens.
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 2sacs de 100kg d’arachide, 10 à 15 paniers de légumes, 2 chargements de charrette  en oranges, 20kg de “geunni”, 5 types de parfums et une vingtaine de bouteilles vides. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages environnants. Elles vendent à domicile, dans les différents marchés et dans les quartiers de façon ambulante,  au comptant souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of group Allakademe are basically married women and have an average age of 34 years , 5 children and live evenly in polygamous and monogamous families in Hamdallaye, one of the communities of Sikasso town, third administrative region of Mali. They are on their fifth loan with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution in order to meet the needs of their clientele. All preceding loans have been repaid. They sell peanut butter, vegetables, oranges and incense. With the new loan, they intend to buy 2bags of 100kilograms of peanuts,10 to 15 baskets of vegetables, 2 carts load of oranges, 20 kg of "geunni", 5 types of perfume and about 20 empty bottles. They get their supplies in the large market of Sikasso town and in the surrounding villages. They sell at home, in different markets and from door to door in the community, for cash and often for credit to a clientele made up of men and women. They intend to realize each of them a monthly profit of 15.000FCFA of which a part will be used for saving and the needs of the family, and the other part will be invested in the business.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Danusha

texts.en:
Danusha is a 28-year-old married woman with one daughter living in Kamburugamuwa, Sri Lanka. She and her husband work together in a tailoring business that they have been running for two years now. They are both very hardworking and have seen success because there is a strong market for their tailoring services.

Danusha is seeking a 20,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to develop her business further. With the loan, she plans to buy cloth and other materials necessary for tailoring.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy cloth and other materials

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en: Mwanaisha is a 36-year-old widow and mother of four children. She lives with her family in Likoni, Mombasa. Mwanaisha makes and sells juice. This she initiated in 2005 to supplement her other business (selling new clothes). Her clients mostly are schoolchildren and the local community. She uses water, sugar, juice coloring detergent and packages. All this she buys in Mombasa town. To cope with the demand, Mwanaisha needs Kshs 20,000 to further expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of plastic plates

loans.name: Jiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Jiguiya sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  ayant en moyenne 39 ans,  5 enfants et vivant à égalité dans les familles polygames et monogames à Hamdallaye  un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur huitième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et tous les prêts précédents ont été  correctement remboursés. 
Elles font la vente  de céréales,  de pagnes wax, de savons et d’articles divers de boutique (cigarettes, bonbons, allumettes, dattes etc.).
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 4sacs de 100kg de riz, une douzaine de cartouches de cigarettes de marques différentes, 10 pièces de pagnes wax, 5 centaines de morceaux de savons traditionnels et 7colis divers articles (bonbons, allumettes, dattes etc.). .
Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages environnants. Elles vendent  à domicile, dans les marchés et dans les quartiers de façon ambulante. Elles vendent au comptant souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the group Jiguiya mainly married women averaging 39 years old, with 5 children who live equally in polygamous and monogamous families. They live in Hamdallaye, one of the neighborhoods in the town of Sikasso which is in the third administrative region of Mali. They are on their eighth collaboration with the micro-finance institution of Soro Yiriwaso so that they can meet the needs of their customers. All of their previous loans have been accurately repaid. They sell grains, pagnes wax (colorful cloth), soap and an array of corner-store goods (cigarettes, candies, matches, dates etc.) With their new loan count on buying four 100 kg bags of rice, a dozen cartons of cigarettes (various brands,) 10 pieces of pagnes wax (cloth,) 500 bars of traditional soap and seven parcels of various other items (candies, matches, dates etc.). They stock up at the main market in Sikasso and in the surrounding villages. They sell from home, at market, and in the neighborhood via rolling carts. They accept both cash and credit to a mixed clientele of men and women. They plan to each make a monthly profit of on average 30,000 FCFA from which one portion will cover the needs of their families or put into savings and the other portion will be invested in their business.

Translated from French by Colleen Creegan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of an array of goods

loans.name: Deogratius

texts.en: Deogratius L. is an entrepreneurial married businessman. He runs a hardware shop in Yombo Vituka Dar es Salaam. He purchases the business materials from the wholesale and retail shops at Kariakoo city shopping center. He managed to build a residential house at Yombo Kilakala where he lives with his family. He also meets his family's daily demands. He has been borrowing from YOSEFO MFI since 1998 when it started. He is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,600,000 to capitalize the business by buying more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Sheilla

texts.en: Sheilla is 28 years old. She is a married mother of two children. Sheilla owns a retail shop in Likoni, which she initiated in 2007 as a supplement to her previous business. She sells essential commodities used in the community such as sugar, flour, cooking oil, rice, beans and kerosene. She gets her stock from wholesalers in Mombasa town. She says that her stock level has gone down due to limited funds, thus she needs Kshs 30,000 to buy stock in bulk.

loans.use: To purchase more stock in bulk

loans.name: Ablavi Hanu

texts.en: Ablavi Hanu N. is 28 years old and works in Lomé, Togo selling eggs. She is married to a carpenter and does not have children. She began her business in 2009 and is now asking for her first loan from WAGES. She will use this loan to purchase over 60 cartons of eggs. With this loan, Mrs. N. will be able to better serve her customers and continue to contribute to her family’s expenses.

loans.use: To purchase more eggs for resale.
